['What kind of research is used to back the use of these tools?', 'The use of these tools is often backed by social science research in consumer behavior, behavioral finance, and cognitive studies.']

['How can the humanities be beneficial for businesses?', 'But looking to the humanities to understand business is an opportunity to engage business in subjects and ideas that have a tremendous, if often overlooked, impact on people.']

['What does the text state?', 'After all, literature that has stood the test of time can provide tremendous insight into human behavior, and Homer or Shakespeare may be more relevant to contemporary executive leadership than a business seminar on how to motivate employees.']
['What did the class cover?', 'In fact, we could argue that anything that makes an impact on people should legitimately be within the scope of business.']
['What did Richard DeGeorge describe?', 'Richard DeGeorge (1933–) of the University of Kansas describes what adding the humanities to business education entails:']

['What was the introduction to the passage?', 'In DeGeorge’s humanities model, business ethics would not prepare students to do certain things, for which they likely will be trained by their employers, but to be certain persons.']

["What is DeGeorge's humanities model?", 'DeGeorge suggests that “a course in the philosophy of business would enable students to think about the foundations of business—its values, ends, purpose, and justification . . . philosophy could add a critical element to business education, an element that would keep business education always alive and prevent it from becoming an accepted, orthodox ideology.']
['What is important to know about this model?', '”38']

['What is the most important aspect of this material?', 'Finally, if normative business ethics is to recognize and, ultimately, be based on the individual, it must address another human trait: bias.']
['What do biases affect?', 'Intellectual, emotional, and social biases affect all decision-making, including those of an ethical nature.']
['Is bias good or bad?', 'Some bias is good, as in having a favorable disposition toward those who work hard in intellectually honest ways.']
['What is important about bias?', 'Bias also rewards those who support and nurture the best elements of a culture, whether corporate, social, or political.']

['What is dangerous about bias?', 'But it becomes dangerous when people use it to blind themselves to the reality around them, reinforce hardened positions even in the face of contradictory evidence, and shirk their responsibility as moral beings.']
['What kind of bias do you think that a firm can have?', 'An example of bias occurs when employees engage in unethical activity because it has been sanctioned by higher-ups.']
['How do employees abdicate personal responsibility?', 'They abdicate personal responsibility by assigning blame elsewhere.']

['What happens when we abdicate personal responsibility?', 'However, no amount of rationalization of the fear of job loss, financial pressure, desire to please a supervisor, and the rest, can justify such behavior, because it diminishes moral agency, the self-awareness, freedom, and ability to make choices based on our perception of right and wrong.']
['What does business ethics want to accomplish by allowing moral agency?', 'And such agency needs to be at the heart of business ethics.']

['What are some other important aspects of business ethics?', 'After all, we cannot make a commitment to serve customers, develop leaders, and improve life for all stakeholders unless there is freedom and moral agency, the necessary ingredients in establishing an attitude of concern, that is, respect for oneself and for others, including all appropriate stakeholders.']
['What is the most important thing you want to know about the course?', 'A contemporary corporation always owes an ethical, and in some cases legal, duty to employees to be a responsible employer.']

['what is this responsibility?', 'In a business context, the definition of this responsibility includes providing a safe workplace, compensating workers fairly, and treating them with a sense of dignity and equality while respecting at least a minimum of their privacy.']
['What are the role models for all employees?', 'Managers should be ethical leaders who serve as role models and mentors for all employees.']
['What should managers be doing?', 'A manager’s job, perhaps the most important one, is to give people a reason to come back to work tomorrow.']
['What do good managers model?', 'Good managers model ethical behavior.']

['What do managers have to model?', 'If a corporation expects its employees to act ethically, that behavior must start at the top, where managers hold themselves to a high standard of conduct and can rightly say, “Follow my lead, do as I do.”']
['What are some ways leaders model ethical behavior?', 'At a minimum, leaders model ethical behavior by not violating the law or company policy.']

["What happens if managers don't model ethical behavior?", 'One who says, “Get this deal done, I don’t care what it takes,” may very well be sending a message that unethical tactics and violating the spirit, if not the letter, of the law are acceptable.']

["What else can managers do that doesn't model ethical behavior?", 'A manager who abuses company property by taking home office supplies or using the company’s computers for personal business but then disciplines any employee who does the same is not modeling ethical behavior.']

['What other examples of unethical behavior are mentioned?', 'Likewise, a manager who consistently leaves early but expects all other employees to stay until the last minute is not demonstrating fairness.']
['What other things do businesses owe to their workforce?', 'Another responsibility business owes the workforce is transparency.']
['What is the duty of a company to be transparent?', 'This duty begins during the hiring process, when the company communicates to potential employees exactly what is expected of them.']
['What is important that business owes to their workforce?', 'Once hired, employees should receive training on the company rules and expectations.']
['What else should management do to help employees?', 'Management should explain how an employee’s work contributes to the achievement of company-wide goals.']

['What else can you tell me about the passage?', 'In other words, a company owes it to its employees to keep them in the loop about significant matters that affect them and their job, whether good or bad, formal or informal.']
['What does this help them do?', 'A more complete understanding of all relevant information usually results in a better working relationship.']
['What is full transparency?', 'That said, some occasions do arise when full transparency may not be warranted.']

['What are some examples of confidential negotiations?', 'If a company is in the midst of confidential negotiations to acquire, or be acquired by, another firm, this information must be kept secret until a deal has been completed (or abandoned).']
['How is this important?', 'Regulatory statutes and criminal law may require this.']
['What would they require this for?', 'Similarly, any internal personnel performance issues or employee criminal investigations should normally be kept confidential within the ranks of management.']

['What kind of changes should you avoid?', 'Transparency can be especially important to workers in circumstances that involve major changes, such as layoffs, reductions in the workforce, plant closings, and other consequential events.']
['What kind of impact does that have on people?', 'These kinds of events typically have a psychological and financial impact on the entire workforce.']
['What can we do to show leadership?', 'However, some businesses fail to show leadership at the most crucial times.']

['What can you do to stand behind it?', 'A leader who is honest and open with the employees should be able to say, “This is a very difficult decision, but one that I made and will stand behind and accept responsibility for it.”']

['What is doublespeak?', 'To workers, euphemisms such as “right sizing” to describe layoffs and job loss only sounds like corporate doublespeak designed to help managers justify, and thereby feel better (and minimize guilt), about their (or the company’s) decisions.']

['What is the difference between doublespeak and a severance package?', 'An ethical company will give workers advance notice, a severance package, and assistance with the employment search, without being forced to do so by law.']
['What kind of leadership do you think should be followed?', 'Proactive rather than reactive behavior is the ethical and just thing to do.']

['When did this first come to light?', 'Historically, however, a significant number of companies and managers failed to demonstrate ethical leadership in downsizing, eventually leading Congress to take action.']
['What were some of the laws that were passed?', 'The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN)']

['What act has been in effect for almost three decades, protecting workers and their families (as well as their communities) by mandating that employers provide sixty days’ advance notice of mass layoffs and plant closings?', 'Act of 1989 has now been in effect for almost three decades, protecting workers and their families (as well as their communities) by mandating that employers provide sixty days’ advance notice of mass layoffs and plant closings.']
['What was the reason for this law?', 'This law was enacted precisely because companies were not behaving ethically.']

['What is the main idea of the article?', 'A report by the Cornell University Institute of Labor Relations indicated that, prior to passage of WARN, only 20 percent of displaced workers received written advance notice, and those who did received very short notice, usually a few days.']
['What percentage of people had two months’ notice of their impending displacement?', 'Only 7 percent had two months’ notice of their impending displacement.']

["What is significant about the study's findings?", 'Employers typically preferred to get as many days of work as possible from their workforces before a mass layoff or closing, figuring that workers might reduce productivity or look for other jobs sooner if the company were transparent and open about its situation.']
['What other insights did you find interesting?', 'In other words, when companies put their own interests and needs ahead of the workforce, we can hardly call that ethical leadership.']
['What is a management action covered by WARN?', 'Other management actions covered by WARN include outsourcing, automation, and artificial intelligence in the workplace.']

['What does the arguing about management often exceeds mean?', 'Arguably, a company has an ethical duty to notify workers who might be adversely affected even if the WARN law does not apply, demonstrating that the appropriate ethical standard for management often exceeds the minimum requirements of the law.']

['What is the law sometimes often slow to keep up with ethical reflection on best management practices?', 'Put another way, the law sometimes is often slow to keep up with ethical reflection on best management practices.']

['What is the primary federal law ensuring physical safety on the job?', 'The primary federal law ensuring physical safety on the job is the Occupational Safety and Health Act (OSHA), which was passed in 1970.5']

['What does the act say about physical safety on the job?', 'The goal of the law is to ensure that employers provide a workplace environment free of risk to employees’ safety and health, such as mechanical or electrical dangers, toxic chemicals, severe heat or cold, unsanitary conditions, and dangerous equipment.']
['Who enforces the act?', 'OSHA also refers to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, which operates as a division of the Department of Labor and oversees enforcement of the law.']

['What does the act create?', 'This act created the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH), which serves as the research institute for OSHA and enunciates appropriate standards for safety and health on the job.']

['what else is related to these duties?', 'OSHA and related regulations give employees several important rights, including the right to make a confidential complaint with OSHA that might result in an inspection of the workplace, to obtain information about the hazards of the workplace and ways to avoid harm, to obtain and review documentation of work-related illnesses and injuries at the job site, to obtain copies of tests done to measure workplace hazards, and protection against any employer sanctions as a consequence of complaining to OSHA about workplace conditions or hazards.']
['What is the name of the person who can make an anonymous report?', 'A worker who believes his or her OSHA rights are being violated can make an anonymous report.']
['What else was mentioned about anonymous report?', 'OSHA will then establish whether there are reasonable grounds for believing a violation exists.']

['What will happen if an employer is found to be in violation of OSHA?', 'If so, OSHA will conduct an inspection of the workplace and report any findings to the employer and employee, or their representatives, including any steps needed to correct safety and health issues.']
['What does OSHA do?', 'OSHA has the authority to levy significant fines against companies that commit serious violations.']

['What has OSHA done in the past?', 'The largest imposed to date were against BP, the oil company responsible for the largest oil spill in U.S. history, discussed in the feature box on BP Deepwater Horizon Oil Spill and Government Regulation.']
["what else was osha's responsibility?", 'OSHA took into account that seventeen workers died on BP’s rig, Deepwater Horizon, as a result of the initial explosion and fire in April 2010.']
['What did OSHA do?', 'Consequently, rig-worker safety was upgraded by statute.']
['What were the total OSHA penalties issued to BP from 2005 to 2009?', 'Total OSHA penalties issued to BP from 2005 to 2009 exceed $102 million.']

['What is significant about this document?', 'Other large fines issued over the last thirty years include $2.8 million against Union Carbide for violations related to an explosion and fire at its plant in Seadrift, Texas, in March 1991; $8.2 million levied against Samsung Guam in the wake of numerous worksite accidents at Guam’s International Airport in 1995; and $8.7 million against Imperial Sugar in connection with an explosion at the company’s plant in Port Wentworth, Georgia, in February 2008.8']

['What other interesting facts are there?', 'More recently, OSHA fined the producers of The Walking Dead $12,675 (the maximum allowable for a single citation) in the wake of the death of a stuntman working on an episode of the television show in Georgia in July 2017.9']
['Are there any other significant facts about the fines?', 'These fines demonstrate that the agency is serious about trying to protect the environment and workers.']

['How do you think the government can help?', 'However, for some, the question remains whether it is more profitable for a business to gamble on cutting corners on safety and pay the fine if caught than to spend the money ahead of time to make workplaces completely safe.']
['What is significant about OSHA fines?', 'OSHA fines do not really tell the whole story of the penalties for workplace safety issues.']

['What are the other penalties?', 'There can also be significant civil liability exposure and public relations damage, as well as worker compensation payments and adverse media coverage, making an unsafe workplace a very expensive risk on multiple levels.']
['What are the laws concerning the workplace free of harassment of all types?', 'Employers have an ethical and a legal duty to provide a workplace free of harassment of all types.']
['What are the types of harassments?', 'This includes harassment based on sex, race, religion, national origin, and any other protected status, including disability.']
['Are there any other laws that are mentioned?', 'Employees should not be expected to work in an atmosphere where they feel harassed, prejudiced against, or disadvantaged.']

['What are the two complaints most frequently filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission?', 'The two complaints most frequently filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), which strives to eliminate racial, gender, and religious discrimination in the workplace, are sexual harassment and racial harassment.']
['Are they the most common complaints?', 'Together, these categories made up two-thirds of all cases filed during 2017.']
['How many complaints are filed yearly?', 'More than thirty thousand complaints of sexual, gender, racial, or creedal harassment are filed each year, illustrating the frequency of the problem.']
['What are some laws regarding workplace harassment?', 'The EEOC enforces Title VII of the Civil Rights Act (CRA) of 1964, which prohibits workplace discrimination including sexual harassment.']

['What other laws protect workers from discrimination?', '11 (As discussed elsewhere in the text, the CRA also protects employees from discrimination based on race, gender, religion, and national origin.)']

['what is an example of sexual harassment?', 'According to EEOC guidelines, it is unlawful to sexually harass a person because of that person’s sex, either through explicit offers in exchange for sexual favors (known as quid pro quo) or through actions at a broader more systemic level that create a “hostile working environment.”']

['What does sexual harassment look like in an office?', 'Sexual harassment includes unwelcome touching, requests for sexual favors, any other verbal or physical harassment of a sexual nature, offensive remarks based on a person’s sex, and off-color jokes.']

['Who is legally liable for workplace harassment?', 'The harasser can be the victim’s supervisor (which creates company liability the first time it happens) or a peer coworker (which usually creates liability after the second time it happens, assuming the company had notice of the first occurrence).']
['Who can be legally liable?', 'It can even be someone who is not an employee, such as a client or customer, and the law applies to men and women.']
['What does the law say about sexual harassment?', 'Thus, the victim and the harasser both can be either a woman or a man, and offenses include both opposite-sex and same-sex harassment.']

['What kind of incidents are not illegal?', 'Although the law does not prohibit mild teasing, offhand comments, or isolated incidents that are not serious, harassment does become illegal when, according to the law, it is so frequent “that it creates a hostile or offensive work environment or when it is so severe that it results in an adverse employment decision (such as the victim being fired or demoted).']

['What should management do to prevent harassment?', '”12 It is management’s responsibility to prevent harassment through education, training, and enforcement of a policy against it, and failure to do so will result in legal liability for the company.']

['What are two examples of workplace environments that descended into the worst excesses of sexist and other inappropriate behavior?', 'Two relatively recent examples of workplace environments that descended into the worst excesses of sexist and other inappropriate behavior occurred at American Apparel and Uber.']

['What is special about those examples?', 'In both cases, principal leaders were mostly men who engaged in ruthless, no-holds-barred management practices that benefitted only those subordinates who most resembled the leaders themselves.']

['What will happen if that happens?', 'Such environments may thrive for a while, but the long-term consequences can include criminal violations that produce hefty fines and imprisonment, bankruptcy, and radical upheaval in corporate management.']

['What happened to those leaders?', 'At American Apparel and at Uber, these events resulted in the dismissal of each company’s CEO, Dov Charney (who also was the founder of the company) and Travis Kalanick (who was one of the corporation’s founders), respectively.']

['what happened with sexual harassment?', 'In 2017 and 2018, a renewed focus on sexual harassment in the workplace and other inappropriate sexual behaviors brought a stream of accusations against high-profile men in politics, entertainment, sports, and business.']

['What are some of the names of those accusers?', 'They included entertainment industry mogul Harvey Weinstein; Pixar’s John Lasseter; on-air personalities Matt Lauer and Charlie Rose; politicians such as Roy Moore, John Conyers, and Al Franken; and Uber’s Kalanick, to name just a few.']

['What is the EEOC?', 'The workplace harassment problem has continued for many decades despite the EEOC’s enforcement efforts; it remains to be seen whether new public scrutiny will prompt a permanent change in the workplace.']
['What is a notable example of the article?', 'The Ford Motor Company serves as a relevant example.']
['What is the significance of this case?', 'Decades after Ford tried to address sexual harassment at two Chicago-area assembly plants, the abuse at the plants evidently continues.']
['Did they have any legal action?', 'According to legal action filed with the EEOC in the early 1990s, conditions for women working at some Ford auto assembly plants were hostile.']
['What did female employees claim?', 'Female employees alleged they were groped, that men pressed against them and simulated sex acts, and that men even masturbated in front of them.']

['What other things did female workers claim?', 'They further asserted that men would routinely make crude comments about the figures of female coworkers, and graffiti depictions of penises were everywhere—carved into tables, spray painted onto floors, and scribbled on walls.']
['What else did female workers claim?', 'Managers and floor supervisors were accused of giving women better assignments in return for sex and punishing those who refused.']

['What happened after that?', 'In the 1990s, lawsuits and an EEOC action led to a $22 million settlement in which Ford admitted to widespread misconduct and committed to crack down on the offenders.']
['Did Ford learn its lesson?', 'Ford still did not learn its lesson, or, after almost three decades, the memory dimmed and they slipped right back into old habits.']
['Did they ever get another settlement?', 'In August 2017, the EEOC reached a new $10 million settlement with Ford for sexual and racial harassment at the two Chicago plants.']

['How did this affect their brand?', 'Though Ford did not admit any wrongdoing in the recent settlement, it appears that neither millions of dollars in earlier damages nor promises by management led to any serious change.']

['Why is this?', 'The New York Times interviewed some of the women at Ford,15 and Sharon Dunn, who was a party of the first case and is now again a party of the second, said, “For all the good that was supposed to come out of what happened to us, it seems like Ford did nothing.']
['Did she have any other interviews?', 'If I had that choice today, I wouldn’t say a damn word.”']
['What do you think about this?', 'Most people spend at least one-third and possibly as much as one-half of their waking hours at work.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Management, therefore, should make work a place where people can thrive, that fosters an atmosphere in which they can be engaged and productive.']

['What else is important in terms of the workplace?', 'Workers are happier when they like where they work and when they do not have to worry about childcare, health insurance, or being able to leave early on occasion to attend a child’s school play, for example.']
['What kind of work is being considered a good job?', 'For our grandparents’ generation, a good job was dependably steady, and employees tended to stay with the same employer for years.']
['How did people get along with their workers?', 'There were not many extras other than a secure job, health insurance, and a pension plan.']
['What did workers expect in the past?', 'However, today’s workers expect these traditional benefits and more.']

['What are some other things that workers want?', 'They may even be willing to set aside some salary demands in exchange for an environment featuring perquisites (or “perks”; nonmonetary benefits) such as a park-like campus, an on-the-premises gym or recreational center, flextime schedules, on-site day care and dry cleaning, a gourmet coffee house or café, and more time off.']
['What is your focus in the article?', 'This section will explore how savvy managers establish a harmonious, compassionate workplace while still setting expectations of top performance.']

['What are the benefits of happy employees?', 'Happy employees are more productive and more focused, which enhances their performance and leads to better customer treatment, fewer sick days, fewer on-the-job accidents, and less stress and burnout.']

['What are the benefits of happy employees?', 'They are more focused on their work, more creative, and better team players, and they are more likely to help others and demonstrate more leadership qualities.']

['Are there any more important points in this document?', 'Research has identified several pitfalls that managers should avoid if they want to have a good working relationship with their direct reports and, indeed, all their employees.']
['What were other pitfalls that managers should avoid?', 'One is making employees feel like they are just employees.']
['What should you do instead?', 'To be happy at work, employees, instead, need to feel like they know each other, have friends at work, are valued, and belong.']
['What are some examples of other pit falls?', 'Another pitfall is remaining aloof or above your employees.']
['What should you do instead?', 'Taking an authentic interest in who they are as people really does matter.']
["When managers don't listen to their direct reports, what happens?", 'When surveys ask employees, “Do you feel like your boss cares about you?,” too frequently the answer is no.']

['What should managers do to show interest?', 'One way to show caring and interest is to recognize when employees are making progress; another might be to take a personal interest in their lives and families.']

['What else should managers do to acknowledge and recognize their employees?', 'Asking employees to share their ideas and implementing these ideas whenever possible is another form of acknowledgement and recognition.']
['What else should managers do?', 'Pause and highlight important milestones people achieve, and ensure that they feel their contributions are noticed by saying thank you.']
['What good advice to new managers?', 'Good advice to new managers includes making work fun.']

['What is the advice about humor?', 'Allow people to joke around as appropriate so that when mistakes occur they can find humor in the situation and move forward without fixating simply on the downside.']
['What kind of success should new managers celebrate?', 'Celebrate accomplishments.']
['What is the right touch of humor?', 'Camaraderie and the right touch of humor can build a stronger workplace culture.']

['What are some other ways to improve employees?', 'Encourage exercise and sleep rather than long work hours, because those two factors improve employees’ health, focus, attention, creativity, energy, and mood.']

['What is the best way to encourage people to work long hours?', 'In the long run, expecting or encouraging people to regularly work long hours because leaving on time looks bad is counterproductive to the goals of a firm.']
['What other suggestions?', 'Accept that employees need to disengage sometimes.']
['What can you add to this?', 'People who feel they are always working because their management team expects they must remain in touch via e-mail or mobile phone can become tremendously stressed.']
['Why is that?', 'To combat this, companies should not expect their workers to be available around the clock, and workers should not feel compelled to be so available.']

['How does disengagement help?', 'Rather, employers should allow employees to completely disengage regularly so they can focus on their friends and families and tend to their own personal priorities.']

['What are some tips for disconnecting from work?', 'By way of international comparison, according to a recent article in Fortune, Germany and France have actually gone as far as banning work-related e-mails from employers on the weekends, which is a step in the right direction, even if only because disconnecting from work is now mandated by law.17']

['What are the key points of the passage?', 'Employers must decide exactly how to spend the resources they have allocated to labor, and it can be challenging to make the right decision about what to provide workers.']

['How many choices are there for employee benefits?', 'Unlike the purchase of raw materials, utilities, and other budgetary items, which is driven primarily by cost and may present only a few choices, management’s offering of employee benefits can present dozens of options, with costs ranging from minimal to very high.']
['What are the different benefits?', 'Work-at-home programs may actually cost the company very little, for example, whereas health insurance benefits may cost significantly more.']

['What other options do we have?', 'In many other industrialized countries, the government provides (i.e., subsidizes) benefits such as health insurance and retirement plans, so a company does not have to weigh the pros and cons (i.e., do a cost-benefit analysis) of what to offer in this area.']
['What happens in the United States?', 'In the United States, employee benefits become part of a cost-benefit analysis, especially for small and mid-sized companies.']
['Do larger companies today offer benefits?', 'Even larger companies today are debating what benefits to offer.']
['What kind of benefits do managers have to decide on?', 'Management has to decide not only how much money to spend on benefits and perks but precisely what to spend the money on.']
['What other decisions are there?', 'Another decision is what benefit choices management should allow each employee to make, and which choices to make for the workforce as a whole.']

['Are there any other decisions?', 'The best managers communicate regularly with their workforce; as a result, they are more likely to know (and be able inform top management about) the types of perks most desired and most likely to attract and keep good workers.']
['What is one challenge with benefits?', 'Figure 6.6 shows that men and women do not always want the same benefits, which presents a challenge for management.']
['What benefits do women prefer?', 'For instance, many women place about twice as much value as many men do on day care (23%–11%) and on paid family leave (24%–14%).']

['What other benefits do women want?', 'Also valued more highly generally by women than by men are better health insurance, work-from-home options, and flexible hours, whereas more men value an on-site gym and free coffee more than women typically do.']
['What kind of perks do employees value?', 'Age and generation also play a role in the types of perks that employees value.']

['What else do workers aged eighteen to thirty-five rank as most important to them at work?', 'Workers aged eighteen to thirty-five rank career advancement opportunities (32%) and work-life balance (33%) as most important to them at work.']
['What is the most important feature for older workers?', 'However, 42 percent of workers older than thirty-five say work-life balance is the most important feature.']

['What can you tell me about the generation that is a generation that is born in the years 1965–1980?', 'This is likely because Generation X (born in the years 1965–1980) place a high value on opportunities for work-life balance, although, like Baby Boomers (born in the years 1946–1964), they also value salary and a solid retirement plan.']

['Do millennials want flexibility?', 'On the other hand, Millennials (born in the years 1981–1997) appreciate flexibility: having a choice of benefits, paid time off, the ability to telecommute, flexible hours, and opportunities for professional development.']

["What should an employer do if it can't afford this?", 'The menu of benefits and perks thus depends on several variables, such as what the company can afford, whether employees value perks over the more direct benefit of higher pay, what the competition offers, what the industry norm is, and the company’s geographic location.']
['What did Google do in terms of perks?', 'For example, Google is constantly searching for ways to improve the health, well-being, and morale of its “Googlers.”']
['What is the company famous for?', 'The company is famous for offering unusual perks, like bicycles and electric cars to get staff around its sprawling California campus.']

['What other benefits can a company do for their staff?', 'Additional benefits are generous paid parental leave for new parents, on-site childcare centers at one location, paid leaves of absence to pursue further education with tuition covered, and on-site physicians, nurses, and health care.']

['What other perks can companies offer?', 'Other perks are gaming centers, organic gardens, eco-friendly furnishings, a pets-at-work policy, meditation and mindfulness training, and travel insurance and emergency assistance on personal and work-related travel.']

['What other benefits do they have?', 'On the death of a Google employee, his or her spouse or domestic partner is compensated with a check for 50 percent of the employee’s salary each year for a decade.']
["How does this benefit the employee's spouse?", 'In addition, all a deceased employee’s stock options vest immediately for the surviving spouse or domestic partner.']

['Do the children of deceased employees receive benefits?', 'Furthermore, a deceased employee’s children receive $1000 per month until they reach the age of nineteen, or until the age of twenty-three if they are full-time students.']
['What was a good example of a healthy workplace?', 'In addition to offering benefits and perks, managers can foster a healthy workplace by applying good “people skills” as well.']
['What are these?', 'Managers who are respectful, open, transparent, and approachable can achieve two goals simultaneously: a workforce that is happier and also one that is more productive.']
['Are there any other examples of good management?', 'Good management requires constant awareness that each team member is also an individual working to meet both personal and company goals.']

['What do effective managers do?', 'Effective managers act on this by regularly meeting with employees to recognize strengths, identify constructive ways to improve on weaknesses, and help workers realize collective and individual goals.']
['What else was discussed?', 'Ethical businesses and good managers also invest in efforts like performance management and employee training and development.']

['What did they do in training?', 'These commitments call for giving employees frequent and honest feedback about what they do well and where they need improvement, thereby enabling them to develop the skills they need, not only to succeed in the current job but to move on to the next level.']
['What is another responsibility of management?', 'Fostering teamwork by treating people fairly and acknowledging their strengths is also an important responsibility of management.']

['What are some qualities that ethical managers demonstrate?', 'Ethical managers, therefore, demonstrate most, if not all, of the following qualities: cultural awareness, positive attitude, warmth and empathy, authenticity, emotional intelligence, patience, competence, accountability, respectful, and honesty.']

['What can you tell me about the data?', 'The Pew Research Center indicates that over the thirty-five years between 1980 and 2014, the inflation-adjusted hourly wages of most middle-income American workers were nearly stagnant, rising just 6 percent, or an average of less than 0.2 percent, per year.']

['what is the definition of middle class?', '21 (The Pew Research Center defines middle-class adults as those living in households with disposable incomes ranging from 65 percent to 200 percent of the national median, which is approximately $60,000.)']
['What else can you tell me about this data?', 'The data collected by the Economic Policy Institute, a nonprofit, nonpartisan think tank, show the same stagnant trend.']

['What is the difference between the wages of high-income workers and the wages of low-income workers?', '22 Contrast this picture with the wages of high-income workers, which rose 41 percent over the same years.']

['What do people think about this data?', 'Many economists, political leaders, and even business leaders admit that increasing wage and wealth disparities are not a sustainable pattern if the U.S. economy is to succeed in the long term.']
['What is the reason for the low wage growth?', 'Wage growth for all workers must be fair, which, in most cases, means higher wages for low- and middle-income workers.']
['What is the most important thing to know about the data?', 'Figure 6.7 presents evidence of the growth of the income gap in the United Sates since the start of the great recession in 2007.']
['What is the argument for a fair or just wage?', 'No reasonable person, regardless of profession or political party, would dispute that employees are entitled to a fair or just wage.']
['What is the debate about?', 'Rather, it is in the calculation of a fair wage that the debate begins.']
['What is the debate about?', 'Economists, sociologists, psychologists, and politicians all have opinions about this, as have most workers.']

['What are some of the factors that feature in calculations?', 'Some of the factors that feature in calculations are federal and state minimum-wage standards, the cost of living, and the rate of inflation.']
["What is the most important fact that you've learned?", 'Figure 6.8 shows the growth, or lack of growth, in the buying power of a minimum-wage earner since 1940.']
['What happened after that?', 'Compare the twenty-year period of 1949 through 1968 with the fifty-year period from 1968 through 2017.']
['What was the difference in buying power?', 'The difference has created a sobering reality for many workers.']
['What else was significant about the buying power?', 'In the nearly six decades since 1960, the inflation-adjusted real minimum wage actually declined by 23 percent.']

['Why did the minimum wage decline?', 'That means minimum-wage workers did not even break even; the value of their wages declined over fifty years, meaning they have effectively worked half a century with no raise.']

['What is the difference between nominal wage and real wage?', 'In the following chart, nominal wage represents the actual amount of money a worker earns per hour; real wage represents the nominal wage adjusted for inflation.']
['What is significant about the study?', 'We consider real wages because nominal wages do not take into account changes in prices and, therefore, do not measure workers’ actual purchasing power.']

['What are the positive developments for minimum-wage workers?', 'One positive development for minimum-wage workers is that state governments have taken the lead in what was once viewed primarily as a federal issue.']
['How many hours a week is the minimum wage?', 'Today, most states have a higher minimum hourly wage than the federal minimum of $7.25.']

['What are the states with the highest minimum hourly wages?', 'States with the highest minimum hourly wages are Washington ($11.50), California and Massachusetts ($11.00), Arizona and Vermont ($10.50), New York and Colorado ($10.40), and Connecticut ($10.00).']
['Is there any other important information we should know?', 'Some cities have even higher minimum hourly wages than under state law; for example, San Francisco and Seattle are at $15.00.']

['What other factors have been contributing to the increase in minimum wages?', 'As of the end of 2017, twenty-nine states had higher minimum hourly wages than the federal rate, according to Bankrate.com.']
['How do you think it remains true that women earn less than men?', 'Even after all possible qualifiers have been added, it remains true that women earn less than men.']

['What do managers offer to justify pay inequities?', 'Managers sometimes offer multiple excuses to justify pay inequities between women and men, such as, “Women take time off for having babies” or “Women have less experience,” but these usually do not explain away the differences.']

['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'The data show that a woman with the same education, experience, and skills, doing the same job as a man, is still likely to earn less, at all levels from bottom to top.']

['What was the study by?', 'According to a study by the Institute for Women’s Policy Research, even women in top positions such as CEO, vice president, and general counsel often earn only about 80 percent of what men with the same job titles earn.']

['What is the highest earnings level?', '24 Data from the EEOC over the five years from 2011 through 2015 for salaries of senior-level officials and managers (defined by the EEOC as those who set broad policy and are responsible for overseeing execution of those policies) show women in these roles earned an average of about $600,000 per year, compared with their male counterparts, who earned more than $800,000 per year.']
['How much difference is there between the two?', '25 That $200,000 difference amounts to a wage gap of about 35 percent each year.']
['Where is it true that women are consistently getting paid less than men?', 'The same is true in mid-level jobs as well.']

['What level jobs are they consistently paid less than men for?', 'In a long-term study of compensation in the energy industry, researchers looked at the job of a land professional—who negotiates with property owners to lease land on which the oil companies then drill wells—and found evidence of women consistently getting paid less than men for doing the same job.']

['What do other research shows about women consistently being paid less than men?', 'Median salaries were compared for male and female land professionals with similar experience (one to five years) and educational background (bachelor’s degree), and men earned $7000 more per year than their female counterparts.']
['Is there a good answer to the question?', 'The answer is yes and no.']

['What was the name of the law that made compensation discrimination illegal?', 'Compensation discrimination has been illegal for more than fifty years under a U.S. law called the Equal Pay Act, passed in 1963.']
['Why does the law still apply?', 'But the problem persists.']
['Are the wages equal?', 'Women earned about 60 percent of what men earned in 1960, and that value had risen to only 80 percent by 2016.']

['What is the plan to rectify this issue?', 'Given these historic rates, women are not projected to reach pay equity until at least 2059, with projections based on recent trends predicting dates as late as 2119.27']

['What are some other interesting things about the article?', 'These are aggregate data; thus, they include women and men with the same job, or similar jobs, or jobs considered to fall in the same general category, but the data do not compare the salary of a secretary to that of a CEO, which would be an unrealistic comparison.']
['What does equal pay mean?', 'Equal pay under the law means equal pay for the “same” job, but not for the “equivalent” job.']

['What about equal pay?', 'Those companies wishing to avoid strict compliance with the law may use several devices to justify unequal pay, including using slightly different job titles, slightly different lists of job duties, and other techniques that lead to different pay for different employees doing essentially the same job.']

['Are women successful in proving compensation discrimination?', 'Women have taken employers to court for decades, only to find their lawsuits unsuccessful because proving individual compensation discrimination is very difficult, especially given that multiple factors can come into play in compensation decisions.']
['Did they win their case?', 'Sometimes class-action lawsuits have been more successful, but even then plaintiffs often lose.']

['What is the significance of this topic?', 'One step would be to pass a new law strengthening the rules on equal pay, but two recent attempts to pass the Paycheck Fairness Act (S.84, H.R.377) and the Fair Pay Act (S.168, H.R.438) narrowly failed.']

['What happened to the bills?', 'These or similar bills, if ever enacted into law, would significantly reduce wage discrimination against those who work in similar job categories by establishing equal pay for “equivalent” work, rather than the current law which uses the term “same” job.']

['What is the pay equivalency?', 'The idea of pay equivalency is closely related to comparable worth, a concept that has been put into action on a limited basis over the years, but never on a large scale.']
['What is comparable worth?', 'Comparable worth holds that workers should be paid on the basis of the worth of their job to the organization.']

['What are some ways to help the problems?', 'Equivalent work and comparable worth can be important next steps in the path to equal pay, but they are challenging to implement because they require rethinking the entire basis for pay decisions.']

['What was the content about?', 'If a woman’s starting salary for the first job of her career is less than that of a man, the initial difference, even if small, tends to cause a systemic, career-long problem in terms of pay equity.']

['Who researched this?', 'Researchers at Temple University and George Mason University found that if a new hire gets $5000 more than another worker hired at the same time, the difference is significantly magnified over time.']

['What else was the article about?', 'Assuming an average annual pay increase of 5 percent, an employee starting with a $55,000 salary will earn at least $600,000 more over a forty-year career than an employee who starts an equivalent job with a $50,000 salary.']

['Did this have a huge impact?', 'This significantly affects many personal decisions, including retirement, because, all other things equal, a lower-paid woman will have to work three years longer than a man to earn the same amount of money over the course of her career.']

['What is the reason that initial pay disparity is heightened over a career?', 'Part of the reason that initial pay disparity is heightened over a career is that when a worker changes jobs, the new employer usually asks what the employee was making in his or her last job and uses that as a baseline for pay in the new job.']

['why does this occur?', 'To combat the problem of history-based pay, which often hurts women, eight states (and numerous municipalities) in the United States now ban employers from asking job applicants to name their last salary.']
['What was the final insight?', 'Although this restriction will not solve the entire problem, it could have a positive effect if it spreads nationally.']

['what else was important?', 'In a survey by the executive search firm Korn Ferry, forty-six of one hundred companies said they usually comply with the legal requirements in force in the strictest of the locations in which they operate, meaning workers in states without this law might not be asked about their salary history during new-job negotiations either.']
['What is the essence of the debate about fair wages?', 'Whether we are discussing fair wages, minimum wages, or equal wages, the essence of the debate often boils down to ethics.']

['How are organizational pay structures set?', 'Organizational pay structures are set by a variety of methods, including internal policies, the advice of outside compensation consultants, and external data, such as market salaries.']
['What is the study material about?', 'An innovative compensation decision in Seattle may provide some insight.']

['Who decided this?', 'In 2011, a young man earning $35,000 a year told his boss at Gravity, a credit-card payments business, that his earnings were not sufficient for a decent life in expensive Seattle.']
['Who was the boss?', 'The boss, Dan Price, who cofounded the company in 2004, was somewhat surprised as he had always taken pride in treating employees well.']
['What did Price think about the decision?', 'Nevertheless, he decided his employee was right.']
['How did Gravity do it?', 'For the next three years, Gravity gave every employee a 20 percent annual raise.']
['How did the new raise go?', 'Still, profit continued to outgrow wages.']
['What did Price do after this?', 'So Price announced that over the next three years, Gravity would phase in a minimum salary of $70,000 for all employees.']
['How did Price get to that point?', 'He reduced his own salary from $1 million to $70,000, to demonstrate the point and help fund it.']

['What happened after that?', 'The following week, five thousand people applied for jobs at Gravity, including a Yahoo executive who took a pay cut to transfer to a company she considered fun and meaningful to work for.']
['What was the national debate about?', 'Price’s decision started a national debate:']
['Why did they raise the price?', 'Since 2000, U.S. productivity has increased 22 percent, yet inflation-adjusted median wages have increased only 2 percent.']

['What does this mean for the business?', 'That means a larger share of capitalism’s rewards are going to shareholders and top executives (who already earn an average of three hundred times more than typical workers, up from seventy times more just a decade ago), and a smaller share is going to workers.']

["What can you tell me about Gravity's decision?", 'If Gravity profits while sharing the benefits of capitalism more broadly, Price’s actions will be seen as demonstrating that underpaying the workforce hurts employers.']
['What does it look like if it fails?', 'If it fails, it may look like proof that companies should not overpay.']

['What was the study about?', 'Price recognized that low starting salaries were antithetical to his values and felt that struggling employees would not be motivated to maintain the high quality that made his company successful with that compensation.']

['What else did you learn about this study?', 'He calls the $70,000 minimum wage an ethical and moral imperative rather than a business strategy, and, though it will cost Gravity about $2 million per year, he has ruled out price increases and layoffs.']
['Did he find anything else interesting?', 'More than half the initial cost was offset by his own pay cut, the rest by profit.']
["What was the result of the company's success?", 'Revenue continues to grow at Gravity, along with the customer base and the workforce.']
['How does retention rate compare to the other study?', 'Currently, the firm has a retention rate of 91 percent.']
['What is the retention rate for the study in which Price was the manager?', '37 Yet Price says managers’ scorecards should measure purpose, impact, and service, as much as profit.']

['What is the article about?', 'Michael Wheeler, a professor at Harvard Business School who teaches a course called “Negotiation and The Moral Leader,” recently discussed the aftermath of Dan Price’s decision at Gravity.']

["How did Price's discussion go?", 'He interviewed other entrepreneurs about their plans for creative compensation to help develop a happy and motivated workforce, and it appears that some other companies are taking notice of how successful Gravity has been since Price made the decision to pay his workers more.']

['What did Driscoll do after hearing Dan Price speak?', 'One of these entrepreneurs was Megan Driscoll, the CEO of Pharmalogics Recruiting, who, after hearing Dan Price speak to a group of executives, was inspired to raise the starting base pay of her employees by 33 percent.']
['What did this do for Driscoll?', 'When Driscoll put her plan to work, her business had forty-six employees and $6.7 million in revenue.']
['What was the year after that?', 'A year later, staff and revenues had jumped to seventy-two and $15 million, respectively.']
['What did Driscoll do after the pay raise?', 'Driscoll points to data showing her people are working harder and smarter after the pay raise than before.']
['What happened after that?', 'There has been a 32 percent increase in clients, and the client retention rate doubled to 80 percent.']
['What happened at Tower Paddleboards?', 'Stephan Aarstol, CEO of Tower Paddleboards, wanted to give his workers a raise, but his company did not have the cash.']
['What did Aarstol do instead?', 'Instead, Aarstol boldly cut the work day to five hours from the ten hours most employees had been working.']
['What did that mean for the company?', 'Essentially that doubled their pay, and as a result, he says, employee focus and engagement have skyrocketed, as have company profits.']
['What kind of compensation does it provide?', 'Managers must carefully balance the short term, such as quarterly profits, versus long-term sustainability as a successful company.']

['What does it require to recognize the value of work that each person contributes?', 'This requires recognizing the value of work that each person contributes and devising a fair, and sometimes creative, compensation plan.']

['What do you think is important about the article?', 'Americans’ longstanding belief in individualism makes some managers wonder why employees would want or need to be represented by a labor union.']

['Why would a CEO want to be represented by an attorney when negotiating an employment contract?', 'The answer is, for the same reasons a CEO wants to be represented by an attorney when negotiating an employment contract, or that an entertainer wants to be represented by an agent.']

['What do unions do?', 'Unions act as the agent/lawyer/negotiator for employees during collective bargaining, a negotiation process aimed at getting management’s agreement to a fair employment contract for members of the union.']
['How does that work?', 'Everyone wants to be successful in any important negotiation, and people often turn to professionals to help them in such a situation.']

['What is the concept of worker organization about?', 'However, in the United States, as elsewhere around the globe, the concept of worker organization has been about more than simply good representation.']

['What has been at the core of debates related to class economics, political power, and ethical values?', 'Unionization and worker rights have often been at the core of debates related to class economics, political power, and ethical values.']
['What are legitimate points on each side of the union debate?', 'There are legitimate points on each side of the union debate.']
['What is a topic that produces significant disagreement?', 'The value of unions is a topic that produces significant disagreement.']

['what are some benefits?', 'Historically, unions have attained many improvements for workers in terms of wages and benefits, standardized employment practices, labor protections (e.g., child labor laws), workplace environment, and on-the-job safety.']
['What are some criticisms of unions?', 'Nevertheless, sometimes unions have acted in their own interests to sustain their own existence, without primary concern for the workers they represent.']

['What does the video in the following Link to Learning tell you?', 'The history of the worker movement (summarized in the video in the following Link to Learning) reveals that in the first half of the twentieth century, wages were abysmally low, few workplace safety laws existed, and exploitive working conditions allowed businesses to use child labor.']
['What did the unions do?', 'Unions stepped in and played an important role in leveling the playing field by representing the interests of the workers.']
['Did unions help?', 'Union membership grew to a relatively high level (33% of wage and salary workers) in the 1950s, and unions became a force in politics.']

['What was the outcome of this?', 'However, their dominance was relatively short-lived, not least because in the 1960s, the federal government started to enact employment laws that codified many of the worker protections unions had championed.']
['What else is significant?', 'In the 1980s and 1990s, the U.S. economy gradually evolved from manufacturing, where unions were strong, to services, where unions were not as prevalent.']

['What was the challenge of organizing in the service sector?', 'The service sector is more difficult to organize, due to a variety of factors such as the historical absence of unions in the sector, workers’ widely differing work functions and schedules, challenging organizational status, and white-collar bias against unions.']

['What developments, along with the appearance of state right-to-work laws, have led to a decline in unions and their membership?', 'These developments, along with the appearance of state right-to-work laws, have led to a decline in unions and their membership.']

['What is the reason for this?', 'Right-to-work laws give workers the option of not joining the union, even at companies where the majority has voted to be represented by a union, resulting in lower membership.']

['What else did the right to work laws do?', 'Right-to-work laws attempt to counter the concept of a union shop or closed shop, which requires that all new hires automatically be enrolled in the labor union appropriate to their job function and that union dues automatically be deducted from their pay.']

['What is the topic of our second reading?', 'Some question the fairness of right-to-work laws, because they allow those who do not join the union to get the same pay and benefits as those who do join and who pay unions dues for their representation.']
['What is the opposite view of the union?', 'On the other hand, right-to-work laws provide workers the right of choice; those who do not want to join a union are not forced to do so.']
['What is the issue with unions?', 'Those who do not choose to join may end up having a strained relationship with union workers, however, when a union-mandated strike occurs.']
['Is it just a union strike?', 'Some non-union members, and even union members, elect to cross the picket line and continue to work.']

["What is the union's reaction to scabs?", 'Traditionally, these “scabs,” as they are derisively labeled by unions, have faced both overt and subtle retaliation at the hands of their coworkers, who prioritize loyalty to the union.']
['What state has right-to-work laws?', 'Twenty-eight states have right-to-work laws.']

['What is a good example of one such state?', 'Notice that many right-to-work states, such as Michigan, Missouri, Indiana, Wisconsin, Kentucky, Tennessee, Alabama, and Mississippi, are among the top ten states where automobiles are manufactured and unions once were strong.']

['what is the largest union in america?', 'According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, total union membership in the United States dropped to 20 percent of the workforce in 1980; by 2016, it was down to about half that.41 Public sector (government) workers have a relatively high union membership rate of 35 percent, more than five times that of private-sector workers, which is at an all-time low of 6.5 percent.']

['What occupations have the highest union membership rate?', 'White-collar workers in education and training, as well as first responders such as police and firefighters now have some of the highest unionization rates, also 35 percent.']

['What are the state union membership rates?', 'Among states, New York continues to have the highest union membership rate at 23 percent, whereas South Carolina has the lowest, at slightly more than 1 percent.']

['What does codetermination mean?', 'Codetermination is a workplace concept that goes beyond unionization to embrace shared governance, in which management and workers cooperate in decision-making and workers have the right to participate on the board of directors of their company.']
['What level of representation does it involve?', 'Board-level representation by employees is widespread in European Union countries.']
['What do codetermination laws apply to?', 'Most codetermination laws apply to companies over a certain size.']
['What size of company do they apply to?', 'For example, in Germany, they apply to companies with more than five hundred employees.']

['What about the US?', 'The labor union movement never has been quite as strong in the United States as in Europe—the trade-union movement began in Europe and remains more vibrant there even today—and codetermination is thus not common in U.S. companies.']
['What was the evidence you found that codetermination has worked?', 'Codetermination has worked relatively well in some countries.']

['What is one example of this?', 'For example, in Germany, workers, managers, and the public at large support the system, and it has often resulted in workers who are more engaged and have a real voice in their workplaces.']

['What are some of the benefits of the new system?', 'Management and labor have cooperated, which, in turn, has led to higher productivity, fewer strikes, better pay, and safer working conditions for employees, which is a classic win-win for both sides.']

['What do some managers, politicians, and even members of the general public believe about unions?', 'Some managers, politicians, and even members of the general public believe unions are a big part of the reason that U.S. companies have difficulty competing in the global economy.']

['What studies indicated this?', 'The conservative think tank Heritage Foundation conducted a study that concluded unions may be responsible, in part, for a slower work process and reduced productivity.']
['What other studies have shown the same thing?', '44 However, multiple other studies indicate that U.S. productivity is up.45']
['What percentage of productivity increased in the United States from 1973 to 2016?', 'Productivity in the United States increased 74 percent in the period 1973 to 2016, according to the OECD.']

['What is the global ranking of the United States?', 'In global productivity rankings, most studies indicate the United States ranks quite high, among the top five or six countries in the world and number two on the list compiled by the OECD.']
['What is Pay and productivity?', 'During the same period as the productivity gains discussed in the preceding paragraph, 1973 to 2016, wages for U.S. workers increased only 12 percent.']
['What are the implications of this?', 'In other words, productivity has grown six times more than pay.']
['What does this mean?', 'Taken together, these facts mean that American workers, union members or not, should not shoulder the blame for competitive challenges faced by U.S. companies.']
['Are they the best employees?', 'Instead, they are a relative bargain for most companies.']
['Who collected this data?', 'Figure 6.12 compares productivity and pay and demonstrates the growing disparity between the two, based on data collected by the Economic Policy Institute.']
['What is this document about?', 'We gain yet another perspective on labor by looking at management compensation relative to that of employees.']
['What are the findings of this study?', 'Between 1978 and 2014, inflation-adjusted CEO pay increased by almost 1,000 percent in the United States, while worker pay rose 11 percent.']

['What is a popular way to compare the fairness of a company’s compensation system with that in other countries?', '47 A popular way to compare the fairness of a company’s compensation system with that in other countries is the widely reported pay ratio, which measures how many times greater CEO pay is than the wages for the average employee.']
['How many times does the average multiplier effect increase?', 'The average multiplier effect in the United States is in the range of three hundred.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means that CEO pay is, on average, three hundred times as high as the pay of the average worker in the same company.']
['What is the multiplier in the United Kingdom?', 'In the United Kingdom, the multiplier is twenty-two; in France, it is fifteen; and in Germany, it is twelve.']

['What are stock options?', 'A large part of executive compensation is in the form of stock options, which frequently are included in the calculation of an executive’s salary and benefits, rather than direct salary.']
['What is interesting about the passage?', 'However, this, in turn, raises the question of whether all or a portion of the general workforce should also share in some form of stock options.']
['What did you find most interesting about this section?', 'Everyone wants to be paid fairly for their work.']
['What did you find interesting about the section?', 'Whether CEO or administrative assistant, engineer or assembly-line worker, we naturally look out for our own best interest.']
['What did you find interesting about this passage?', 'Thus, management compensation is a topic that often causes resentment among the rank and file, especially when organized workers go on strike.']
['What did you find interesting about the passage?', 'From the employee viewpoint, the question is why management often wants to hold the line when it comes to everyone’s wages but their own.']

['What are the elements of legal and ethical aspects of electronic monitoring?', 'Monitored workstations, cameras, microphones, and other electronic monitoring devices permit employers to oversee virtually every aspect of employees’ at-work behavior.']

['What can the employer monitor at work?', 'Technology also allows employers to monitor every aspect of computer use by employees, such as downloads of software and documents, Internet use, images displayed, time a computer has been idle, number of keystrokes per hour, words typed, and the content of e-mails.']

['Who is the survey conducted by?', 'According to a survey by the American Management Association, 48 percent of employers used a form of video monitoring in the workplace, and 67 percent monitored employee Internet use.']
['What does this survey lead to?', 'In 30 percent of the organizations responding to the survey, this electronic monitoring had ultimately led to an employee’s termination.']
['What laws and regulations are involved?', 'The laws and regulations governing electronic monitoring are somewhat indirect and inconsistent.']
['What is the most important thing to know about federal privacy laws?', 'Very few specific federal statutes directly regulate private employers when it comes to broad workplace privacy issues.']

['Is there anything else you need to know?', 'However, monitoring is subject to various state rules under both statutory and common law, and sometimes federal and state constitutional provisions as well.']

['What are the two primary areas of the law related to workplace monitoring?', 'The two primary areas of the law related to workplace monitoring are a federal statute called the Electronic Communications Privacy Act of 1986 (ECPA) and various state common law protections against invasion of privacy.']

['How does this help us?', 'Although the ECPA may appear to prohibit an employer from monitoring its employees’ oral, wire, and electronic communications, it contains two big exceptions that weaken its protection of employees’ rights.']
['What is one of those exceptions?', 'One is the business purpose exception.']

['What does this exception allow?', 'This allows employers—on the basis of legitimate business purposes—to monitor electronic and oral communications, and employers generally assert a legitimate business purpose to be present.']

['What other exceptions do we have to be aware of?', 'The other widely used exception is the consent exception, which allows employers to monitor employee communications provided employees have given their consent.']

['What does the definition of electronic communication apply to?', 'According to the Society for Human Resource Management, the ECPA definition of electronic communication applies to the electronic transmission of communications but not to their electronic storage.']
['What does this mean for the employee?', 'Therefore, courts have distinguished between monitoring electronic communications such as e-mail during transmission and viewing e-mails in storage.']

['What is the difference between viewing stored e-mail and viewing emails during transmission?', 'Viewing emails during transmission is broadly allowed, whereas viewing stored e-mail is considered similar to searching an employee’s private papers and thus is not routinely allowed under the ECPA unless certain circumstances apply (e.g., the e-mails are stored in the employer’s computer systems).']

["What are the legal aspects of monitoring employees' use of company property?", 'In general, it is legal for a company to monitor the use of its own property, including but not limited to computers, laptops, and cell phones.']

['What are the other aspects?', 'According to the ECPA, an employer-provided computer system is the property of the employer, and when the employer provides employees with a laptop they can take home, it likely violates no laws when it monitors everything employees do with that computer, whether business-related or personal.']

['What else is true?', 'The same is true of an employer-provided cell phone or tablet, and always true when an employer gives employees notice of a written policy regarding electronic monitoring of equipment supplied by the company.']
['What is true of equipment owned by the employee?', 'Generally, the same is not true of equipment owned by the employee, such as a personal cell phone.']
['What is the difference between surveillance and tracking?', 'However, an important distinction is based on the issue of consent.']

['Does this include any other parts of the electronic communications?', 'The consent provision in the ECPA is not limited to business communications only; therefore, a company might be able to assert the right to monitor personal electronic communications if it can show employee consent (although this is very likely to worry employees, as discussed in the next section).']
['What is another consideration?', 'Another consideration is whose e-mail server is being used.']

['Does it matter who logs into the mail server?', 'The ECPA and some state laws generally make it illegal for employers to intercept private e-mail by using an employee’s personal log-on/user ID/password information.']
['What did the ECPA and National Labor Relations do?', 'Although the ECPA and National Labor Relations']

['What are both federal laws, individual states are free to pass laws that impose greater limitations, and several states have done so?', 'Act are both federal laws, individual states are free to pass laws that impose greater limitations, and several states have done so.']
['What other laws have they passed?', 'Some require employers to provide employees advance written notice that specifies the types or methods of monitoring to which they will be subjected.']

['What are some examples of state laws creating some degree of protection for workers?', 'Examples of state laws creating some degree of protection for workers include laws in California and Pennsylvania that require consent of both parties before any conversation can be monitored or recorded.']
['What does this tell us?', 'Employees can bring common law privacy claims to challenge employer monitoring.']
['What is a common law?', '(Common laws are those based on prior court decisions rather than on legislatively enacted statutes.)']

['What is the employee required to do?', 'To prevail on a common law claim of invasion of privacy, which is a tort, the employee must demonstrate a right to privacy with respect to the information being monitored.']

['Do the state constitutions have any laws against electronic monitoring?', 'Several state constitutions, such as those in Louisiana, Florida, South Carolina, and California, expressly provide citizens a right to privacy, which may protect employees with respect to monitoring of their personal electronic information and personal communication in the workplace.']

['What is one additional regulatory consideration applicable to electronic monitoring?', 'One additional regulatory consideration applicable to electronic monitoring is whether the company’s workforce is unionized.']

['What did the National Labor Relations Board rule?', 'The National Labor Relations Board, the federal labor law agency, has ruled that the video surveillance of any portion of the workplace is a condition of employment subject to collective bargaining and must be agreed to by the union before implementation, so employees have notice.']

['What is the difference between a union and a non-unionized workplace?', 'If a workplace is not unionized (the majority are not), then this federal regulation requiring notice does not apply, and as stated previously in this chapter, if there is any protection at all, it would have to be given by state regulation (which is rare in the private [nongovernmental] sector).']
['What is significant about the material?', 'Many employees generally are not be familiar with the specific details of the law.']
['What should be known about the employees?', 'They may feel offended by monitoring, especially of their own equipment.']

['What do they need to determine?', 'Most workers do not have employment contracts, so there may not be a specific agreement between the two parties detailing their mutual responsibilities.']
['What happens if there is no agreement?', 'Instead, the common law (case law) of agency in each state is often the source of the rules governing an employment relationship.']

['What is the usual depiction of duty in common law?', 'The usual depiction of duty in common law is the duty of loyalty, which, in all fifty states, requires that an employee refrain from acting in a manner contrary to the employer’s interest.']

['What does the article say about the duty of care?', 'This duty creates some basic rules employees must follow on the job and provides employers with enforceable rights against employees who violate them.']

['What does the duty of loyalty mean?', 'In general terms, the duty of loyalty means an employee is obligated to render “loyal and faithful” service to the employer, to act with “good faith,” and not to compete with but rather to advance the employer’s interests.']

['What are some things that an employee must not do?', 'The employee must not act in a way that benefits him- or herself (or any other third party), especially when doing so would create a conflict of interest with the employer.']

['Can an employee hold two jobs if it would compete or conflict with the first job?', 'The common law of most states holds as a general rule that, without asking for and receiving the employer’s consent, an employee cannot hold a second job if it would compete or conflict with the first job.']

['What are the most common reasons for not holding two jobs?', 'Thus, although the precise boundaries of this aspect of the duty of loyalty are unclear, an employee who works in the graphic design department of a large advertising agency in all likelihood cannot moonlight on the weekend for a friend’s small web design business.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'However, employers often grant permission for employees to work in positions that do not compete or interfere with their principal jobs.']

['What is an example of this?', 'The graphic designer might work for a friend’s catering business, for example, or perhaps as a wedding photographer or editor of a blog for a public interest community group.']

['What are the questions in this article?', 'What is clear is that it is wrong for employees to make work decisions primarily for their own personal gain, rather than doing what is in the employer’s best interest.']

['What other things do employees want their employer to do?', 'An employee might have the authority to decide which other companies the employer will do business with, for example, such as service vendors that maintain the copiers or clean the offices.']
['How does that affect the employee?', 'That gives him or her an incentive to encourage doing business with that particular company, whether it would be best for the employer or not.']
['What is the purpose of this material?', 'The degree to which the duty of loyalty exists is usually related to the degree of responsibility or trust an employer places in an employee.']
['How does the degree relate to trust?', 'More trust equals a stronger duty.']

['What does extensive authority mean?', 'For example, when an employee has very extensive authority or access to confidential information, the duty can rise to its highest level, called a fiduciary duty, which is discussed in an earlier chapter.']
['What is the definition of loyalty?', 'There is no generally agreed-upon definition of an employee’s duty of loyalty to his or her employer.']

['What is one indicator that our understanding of the term is changing?', 'One indicator that our understanding of the term is changing is that millennials are three times more likely than older generations to change jobs, according to a Forbes Human Resources Council survey.3']

['How do they feel about loyalty?', 'About nine in ten millennials (91 percent) say they do not expect to stay with their current job longer than three years, compared with older workers who often anticipated spending ten years or even an entire career with one employer, relying on an implicit social contract between employer and employee that rewarded lifetime employment.']
['What is the concept of loyalty?', 'The Loyalty Research Center, a consulting firm, defines loyal employees as “being committed to the success of the organization.']
