["How does having the employer's best interest at heart relate to loyalty?", 'The other piece is remaining with the same employer rather than moving on.”']

['how does remaining with the same employer relate to loyalty?', 'Bidwell goes on to acknowledge, “There is less a sense that your organization is going to look after you in the way that it used to, which would lead [us] to expect a reduction in loyalty.”']

['What is the first reason that loyalty has different meanings for people?', 'One reason is that loyalty is a two-way street, a feeling developed through the enactment of mutual obligations and responsibilities.']

['How is the term employment contract different from loyalty?', 'However, most employers do not want to be obligated to their workers in a legal sense; they usually require that almost all workers are employees “at will,” that is, without any long-term employment contract.']

['What does it mean when a company says an employee is employed at will?', 'Neither state nor federal law mandates an employment contract, so when a company says an employee is employed at will, it is sending a message that management is not making a long-term commitment to the employee.']

['Are there other examples of why loyalty has different meanings?', 'Employees may naturally feel less loyalty to an organization from which they believe they can be let go at any time and for any legal reason (which is essentially what at-will employment means).']
['What does this mean?', 'Of course, at-will employment also means the employee can also quit at any time.']
['What does freedom to move mean?', 'However, freedom to move is a benefit only if the employee has mobility and a skill set he or she can sell to the highest bidder.']
['What are some examples of at-will employment?', 'Otherwise, for most workers, at-will employment usually works to the employer’s advantage, not the employee’s.']

['What are the concepts of loyalty to an organization?', 'Another reason the concept of loyalty to an organization seems to be changing at all levels is the important role money plays in career decisions.']

['What do subordinates think about their bosses?', 'When they see chief executive officers (CEOs) and other managers leaving to work for the highest bidder, subordinates quickly conclude that they, too, ought to look out for themselves, just as their bosses do, rather than trying to build up seniority with the company.']
['What does switching jobs have to do with this concept of loyalty?', 'Switching jobs can often be a way for employees to improve their salaries.']
['What is a recent example of loyalty that we have to read?', 'Consider professional sports.']

['What happened to the athletes?', 'For decades professional athletes were tied to one team and could not sell their services to the highest bidder, meaning that their salaries were effectively capped.']

['What did the courts do?', 'Finally, after several court decisions (including the Curt Flood reserve clause case involving the St. Louis Cardinals and Major League Baseball),6 players achieved some degree of freedom and can now switch employers frequently in an effort to maximize their earning potential.']
['What other industry benefited the most from the invention of the telephone?', 'The same evolution occurred in the entertainment industry.']

['how was it changed?', 'In the early years of the movie business, actors were tied to studios by contracts that prevented them from making movies for any other studio, effectively limiting their earning power.']

['What happened as a result of the change?', 'Then the entertainment industry changed as actors gained the freedom to sell their services to the highest bidder, becoming much more highly compensated in the process.']

['What are other economic phenomena affecting loyalty in the private sector?', 'Another economic phenomenon affecting loyalty in the private sector was the switch from defined-benefit to defined-contribution retirement plans.']

['What does the pension provide?', 'The employer administers the plan and manages the investment risk, promising the employee a set payout upon retirement.']

['How is the pension different than defined contribution plans?', 'In the defined-contribution plan, however, the employee invests a certain percentage of his or her salary in a retirement fund, often a 401(k) or 403(b) plan, where it is sometimes matched (partially or wholly) by the employer.']

['What are the 403b and 401k plans?', '(These savings plans with their seemingly strange designations are part of the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, and the letter/number combinations indicate subsections of the Code.']

['How do the plans affect loyalty?', 'Defined-benefit plans reward longevity in the firm, whereas defined-contribution plans reward high earnings over seniority.']

['What is confidentiality originated from?', 'Employers are well within their rights to expect employees to honor their duty of confidentiality and maintain the secrecy of such proprietary material.']

['What is a contract?', 'Sometimes the duty of confidentiality originates specifically from an employment contract, if there is one, and if not, the duty still exists in most situations under the common law of agency.']

['What are the reasons for the adoption?', 'Most companies do not consider U.S. common law on confidentiality sufficient protection, so they often adopt employment agreements or contracts with employees that set forth the conditions of confidentiality.']

['What does the contract specify?', '(Note that such contracts define a one-way obligation, from the employee to the employer, so they do not protect the at-will employee from being terminated without cause.)']
['What else is listed in an employment agreement?', 'Typically, an employment agreement will list a variety of requirements.']

['What does a contract usually contain?', 'For example, although in most situations the law would already hold that the employer owns copyrightable works created by employees within the scope of their employment (known as works for hire), a contract usually also contains a specific clause stating that the company owns any and all such works and assigning ownership of them to the company.']
['What else is there?', 'The agreement will also contain a patent assignment provision, stating that all inventions created within the scope of employment are owned by or assigned to the company.']

['What type of confidential information might have economic value?', 'Employers also want to protect their trade secrets, that is, information that has economic value because it is not generally known to the public and is kept secret by reasonable means.']

['What kinds of trade secrets might be sought?', 'Trade secrets might include technical or design information, advertising and marketing plans, and research and development data that would be useful to competitors.']

['What type of agreement is used to protect against the theft of all such information?', 'Often nondisclosure agreements are used to protect against the theft of all such information, most of which is normally protected only by the company’s requirement of secrecy, not by federal intellectual property law.']

['What type of law applies?', 'Federal law generally protects registered trademarks (commercial identifications such as words, designs, logos, slogans, symbols, and trade dress, which is product appearance or packaging) and grants creators copyrights (to protect original literary and artistic expressions such as books, paintings, music, records, plays, movies, and software) and patents (to protect new and useful inventions and configurations of useful articles).']

['What kind of confidentiality do we need?', 'U.S. companies have long used non-compete agreements as a way to provide another layer of confidentiality, ensuring that employees with access to sensitive information will not compete with the company during or for some period after their employment there.']

['What is the stated purpose of such agreements?', 'The stated purpose of such agreements is to protect the company’s intellectual property, which is the manifestation of original ideas protected by legal means such as patent, copyright, or trademark.']

['What is enforceability?', 'To be enforceable, non-compete agreements are usually limited by time and distance (i.e., they are in effect for a certain number of months or years and within a certain radius of the employer’s operations).']

['Are there any other reasons?', 'However, some companies have begun requiring these agreements even from mid- and lower-level workers in an attempt to prevent them from changing jobs, including those who have no access to any confidential intellectual property.']

['Do they like non-compete?', 'The increased use of such agreements has left many employees feeling trapped by their limited mobility.']
['What is the passage about?', 'An ethical question arises regarding whether this practice is in the best interests of society and its workers, and some states are responding.']

['What else did you learn?', 'California enacted a law in 2017 saying that most non-compete agreements are void, holding that although an employee may owe the employer a responsibility not to compete while employed, that duty ceases upon termination of employment.']
['What is another way of saying that an employee does not "belong" to a company forever?', 'In other words, an employee does not “belong” to a company forever.']

['What are the main topics of our study material?', 'Every company puts time, effort, and money into developing a brand, that is, a product or service marketed by a particular company under a particular name.']

['What are the benefits of having a brand?', 'As Apple, Coca-Cola, Amazon, BMW, McDonald’s, and creators of other coveted brands know, branding—creating, differentiating, and maintaining a brand’s image or reputation—is an important way to build company value, sell products and services, and expand corporate goodwill.']

['What is a brand?', 'In the sense discussed here, the term “brand” encompasses an image, reputation, logo, tagline, or specific color scheme that is trademarked, meaning the company owns it and must give permission to others who would legally use it (such as Tiffany’s unique shade of blue).']
['What is the content of respecting the brand?', 'Companies want and expect employees to help in their branding endeavors.']

['How can they make happy customers?', 'For example, according to the head of training at American Express, the company’s brand is its product, and its mantra has always been, “Happy employees make happy customers.']
['Why did they want their employees happy?', '”15 American Express places significant emphasis on employee satisfaction because it is convinced this strategy helps protect and advance its brand.']

['What is another company that has this kind of philosophy?', 'One company that uses positive employee involvement in branding is the technology conglomerate Cisco, which started a branding program on social media that reaches out to employees.']

['What are the benefits of this program?', 'The benefit is that prospective job candidates get a peek into Cisco life, and current employees feel the company trusts and values their ideas.']

['What is that all about?', 'However, protecting the brand can be a special challenge today, thanks to the ease with which customers and even employees can post negative information about the brand on the Internet and social media.']
['How do they gain this negative information?', 'Consider these examples in the fast-food industry.']

['Did Burger King react to this incident?', 'According to a Burger King news release, the buns in the photo were waste material because of an ordering mistake and were promptly discarded after the photo was taken; the employee in the photo was fired.']

['What are some examples of how disloyal or disgruntled employees can create damage?', 'These examples demonstrate how much damage disloyal or disgruntled employees can create, especially on social media.']

['What are the examples of the companies that experienced financial and goodwill losses after the incidents?', 'All three companies experienced financial and goodwill losses after the incidents and struggled to restore public trust in their products.']
['What is the reason for this?', 'The immediate and long-term costs of such incidents are the reason companies invest in developing brand loyalty among their employees.']

['What was the main message of this document?', 'According to a Harvard Business Review interview with Colin Mitchell, global vice president, McDonald’s Brand, McDonald’s, good branding requires that a business think of marketing not just to its customers but also to its employees, because they are the “very people who can make the brand come alive for your customers”.']

['What is internal marketing?', '18 The process of getting employees to believe in the product, to commit to the idea that the company is selling something worth buying, and even to think about buying it, is called internal marketing.']
['What else was mentioned?', 'Of course, some employees may not want to be the equivalent of a company spokesperson.']
['What else did the interview cover?', 'Suppose employers offer employees substantial discounts on their products or services.']
['Why is internal marketing important?', 'Internal marketing is an important part of the solution to the problem of employees who act as if they do not care about the company.']

['What do the fast food examples show about internal marketing?', 'In those cases, it is clear the employees did not believe in the brand and felt hostile toward the company.']

['What should the employees do when they interact with customers?', 'Thus, the ethical obligations of an employee also extend to interactions with customers, whom they should treat with respect.']

['Do you think people should not blow the whistle?', 'Ethicists say it should be done with an appropriate motive—to get the company to comply with the law or to protect potential victims—and not to get revenge on a boss at whom you are angry.']

['What else do you think should be important?', 'Of course, even if an employee has a personal revenge motive, if the company actively is breaking the law, it is still important that the wrongdoing be reported.']
['Do you think the material gives other important info?', 'In any case, knowing when and how to blow the whistle is a challenge for an employee wanting to do the right thing.']

['What are the first questions in this section?', 'Under many federal laws, an employer cannot retaliate by firing, demoting, or taking any other adverse action against workers who report injuries, concerns, or other protected activity.']

['What does that mean?', 'Without the help of employees who are “on the ground” and see the violations occur, it could be difficult for government regulators to always find the source of pollution.']
['What is the text about?', 'Even when whistleblowers are not acting completely altruistically, their revelations may still be true and worthy of being brought to the public’s attention.']

['What are some important facts about the article?', 'Blowing the whistle may bring the employee more than just intrinsic ethical rewards; it may also result in cash.']
['Which law is most lucrative?', 'The most lucrative law under which employees can blow the whistle is the False Claims Act (FCA), 31 U.S.C. §§ 3729–3733.']

['What was the reason Congress enacted the FCA?', 'This legislation was enacted in 1863, during the American Civil War, because Congress was worried that suppliers of goods to the Union Army might cheat the government.']
['What was the FCA?', 'The FCA has been amended many times since then, and today it serves as a leading example of a statutory law that remains important after more than 150 years.']

['What does the government have to pay for a false claim?', 'The FCA provides that any person who knowingly submits false claims to the government must pay a civil penalty for each false claim, plus triple the amount of the government’s damages.']
['How much is the civil penalty?', 'The amount of this basic civil penalty is regularly adjusted by the cost of living, and the current penalty range is from $5500 to $11,000.']

['What is the qui tam provision of the law?', 'More importantly for our discussion, the qui tam provision of the law allows private persons (called relators) to file lawsuits for violations of the FCA on behalf of the government and to receive part of any penalty imposed.']

['What is the difference between a relator and a whistleblower?', 'The person bringing the action is a type of a whistleblower, but one who initiates legal action on his or her own rather than simply reporting it to a government agency.']

['How does the relator receive a portion of the proceeds from a successful case?', 'If the government believes it is a worthwhile case and intervenes in the lawsuit, then the relator (whistleblower) is entitled to receive between 15 and 25 percent of the amount the government recovers.']
['What is the largest percentage of the recovery?', 'If the government thinks winning is a long shot and declines to intervene in the lawsuit, the relator’s share increases to 25 to 30 percent.']

['What is the reward of the whistleblower?', 'It is not just the size of the reward that should get your attention but also the amount of money these employees saved taxpayers and/or shareholders.']

['What is the basic meaning of protections for people with disabilities?', 'In the United States, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), passed in 1990, stipulates that a person has a disability if he or she has a physical or mental impairment that reduces participation in “a major life activity,” such as work.']
['What does the ADA protect people with?', 'An employer may not discriminate in offering employment to an individual who is diagnosed as having such a disability.']
['What does ADA protect?', 'Furthermore, if employment is offered, the employer is obliged to make reasonable accommodations to enable him or her to carry out normal job tasks.']

['What other accommodations are there?', 'Other accommodations could include providing readers, interpreters, or other necessary forms of assistance such as an assistive animal.']

['How are they protected?', 'A key part of complying with the law is understanding and applying the concept of reasonableness: “An employer is required to provide a reasonable accommodation to a qualified applicant or employee with a disability unless the employer can show that the accommodation would be an undue hardship—that is, that it would require significant difficulty or expense.']

['How does this relate to ethics?', 'Once again, being ethical does not mean losing money or performing poorly.']

['What states have such anti-LGBTQ laws?', 'In fact, states that have passed legislation considered anti-LGBTQ by the wider U.S. community, such as the Religious Freedom Restoration Act in Indiana or North Carolina’s H.B. 2, the infamous “bathroom bill” that would require transgender individuals to use the restroom corresponding with their birth certificate, have experienced significant economic pushback.']

['Did H.B. 2 go into effect?', "In 2017, the North Carolina legislature replaced the law, and a 2019 court settlement substantially altered it; however, the remaining North Carolina law limits local municipalities' protections for LGBTQ people."]
['What other anti-LGBTQ laws exist?', 'Indiana’s Religious Freedom Restoration']
['What state brought about the most backlash?', 'Act evoked a similar backlash in 2015 and public criticism from U.S. businesses.']

['What is the Human Rights Campaign?', 'To assess LGBTQ equality policies at a corporate level, the Human Rights Campaign foundation publishes an annual Corporate Equality Index (CEI) of approximately one thousand large U.S. companies and scores each on a scale of 0 to 100 on the basis of how LGBTW-friendly its benefits and employment policies are.']

['What are some examples of large U.S companies?', 'More than six hundred companies recently earned a perfect score in the 2018 CEI, including such household names as AT&T, Boeing, Coca-Cola, Gap Inc., General Motors, Johnson & Johnson, Kellogg, United Parcel Service, and Xerox.28']

['What organization tracks LGBTQ equality and inclusion in the workplace?', 'Another organization tracking LGBTQ equality and inclusion in the workplace is the National LGBT Chamber of Commerce, which issues third-party certification for businesses that are majority-owned by LGBT individuals.']

['What were some facts you found?', 'Data collected by economic researchers at the University of California show that income disparities have become more pronounced over the past thirty-five years, with the top 10 percent of income earners averaging ten times as much income as the bottom 90 percent, and the top 1 percent making more than forty times what the bottom 90 percent does.']

['What is the basic concept discussed?', 'The U.S. economy was built largely on the premise of an expanding and prosperous middle class to which everyone had a chance of belonging.']

['What did the GI Bill and returning prosperity provide veterans with money for?', 'In the years after World War II, the GI Bill and returning prosperity provided veterans with money for education, home mortgages, and even small businesses, all of which helped the economy grow.']

['What else is discussed?', 'Families bought cars and opened credit card accounts.']
['What is discussed in the passage?', 'The culture of the middle class with picket fences, backyard barbecues, and black-and-white televisions had arrived.']

['What television shows reflected the “good life” desired by many in this newly emerging group?', 'Television shows such as Leave it to Beaver and Father Knows Best reflected the “good life” desired by many in this newly emerging group.']
['What else is discussed?', 'By the mid-1960s, middle-class wage earners were fast becoming the engine of the world’s largest economy.']
['What does it mean to be middle class?', 'The middle class is not a homogenous group, however.']

['what does the middle class consist of?', 'For example, split fairly evenly between Democratic and Republican parties, the middle class helped elect Republican George W. Bush in 2004 and Democrat Barack Obama in 2008 and 2012.']
['What is a typical middle class home like?', 'And, of course, a suburban house with a white picket fence represents a consumption economy, which is not everyone’s idea of utopia, nor should it be.']
['What is it really like to be a slave?', 'More importantly, not everyone had equal access to this ideal.']
['What is the middle class?', 'But one thing almost everyone agrees on is that a shrinking middle class is not good for the economy.']
['What is the U.S. middle class growing?', 'Data from the International Monetary Fund indicate the U.S. middle class is going in the wrong direction.']

['What is happening to the middle class?', 'Only one-quarter of 1 percent of all U.S. households have moved up from the middle- to the upper-income bracket since 2000, while twelve times that many have slid to the lower-income bracket.']
['What can you tell me about the middle class?', 'That is a complete reversal from the period between 1970 and 2000, when middle-income households were more likely to move up than down.']
['What is the biggest problem with the middle class?', 'According to Business Insider, the U.S. middle class is “hollowing out, and it’s hurting U.S. economic growth.']

['What are some important aspects of this material?', 'Not only has the total wealth of middle-income families remained flat but the overall percentage of middle-income households in the United States has shrunk from almost 60 percent in 1970 to only 47 percent in 2014, a very significant drop.']

['why does this matter?', 'Because consumers of comfortable means are a huge driver of the U.S. economy, with their household consumption of goods and services like food, energy, and education making up more than two-thirds of the nation’s gross domestic product (GDP), the downward trend is an economic challenge for corporate America and the government.']
['What is the solution to this problem?', 'Business must be part of the solution.']

['What presidents did Robert Reich serve under?', 'Robert Reich was U.S. Secretary of Labor from 1993 to 1997 and served in the administrations of three presidents (Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, and Bill Clinton).']

['What did Reich do at UCLA?', 'He is one of the nation’s leading experts on the labor market and the economy and is currently the chancellor’s professor of Public Policy at University of California, Berkeley, and a senior fellow at the Blum Center for Developing Economies.']
['What did Reich have to do with tech firms?', 'Reich recently told this story: “I was visited in my office by the chairman of one of the country’s biggest high-tech firms.']
['What did he want to talk about?', 'He wanted to talk about the causes and consequences of widening inequality and the shrinking middle class, and what to do about it.”']
['What did Reich do to discuss it?', 'Reich asked the chairman why he was concerned.']
['Why was he concerned?', '“Because the American middle class is the core of our customer base.']
['Did he say anything else?', 'If they can’t afford our products in the years ahead, we’re in deep trouble.']
['What other issues did Reich have to deal with?', '”32']
['What is Reich hearing?', 'Reich is hearing a similar concern from a growing number of business leaders, who see an economy that is leaving out too many people.']

['What is the problem with the economy leaving out too many people?', 'Business leaders know the U.S. economy cannot grow when wages are declining, nor can their businesses succeed over the long term without a growing or at least a stable middle class.']
['What did Reich quote Lloyd Blankfein for?', 'Other business leaders, such as Lloyd Blankfein, CEO of Goldman Sachs, have also said that income inequality is a negative development.']

['What did Reich quote Lloyd Blankfein about?', 'Reich quoted Blankfein: “It is destabilizing the nation and is responsible for the divisions in the country . . . too much of the GDP over the last generation has gone to too few of the people.']
['What happened with the GDP over the last generation?', '”33']

['What are the benefits of raising the minimum wage?', 'Some business leaders, such as Bill Gross, chair of the world’s largest bond-trading firm, suggest raising the federal minimum wage, currently $7.25 per hour for all employers doing any type of business in interstate commerce (e.g., sending or receiving mail out of state) or for any company with more than $500,000 in sales.']

['What can a higher minimum wage do for them?', 'Many business leaders and economists agree that a higher minimum wage would help address at least part of the problem of income inequality; industrialized economies function best when income inequality is minimal, according to Gross and others who advocate for policies that bring the power of workers and corporations back into balance.']
['What is the minimum wage in dollars?', '34 A hike in the minimum wage affects middle-class workers in two ways.']

['What are the two ways that the tax cut helps the middle class?', 'First, it is a direct help to those who are part of a two-earner family at the lower end of the middle class, giving them more income to spend on necessities.']
['What does it help them with?', 'Second, many higher-paid workers earn a wage that is tied to the minimum wage.']
['How would that affect them?', 'Their salaries would increase as well.']

['What was the first thing you learned about income inequality?', 'Without congressional action to raise the minimum wage, states have taken the lead, along with businesses that are voluntarily raising their own minimum wage.']
['What is the minimum wage in your state?', 'Twenty-nine states have minimum wages that exceed the federal rate of $7.25 per hour.']

['What kind of businesses have raised the minimum wage?', 'Costco, T.J. Maxx, Marshalls, Ikea, Starbucks, Gap, In-and-Out Burger, Whole Foods, Ben & Jerry’s, Shake Shack, and McDonalds have also raised minimum wages in the past two years.']

['What kind of banks raised their minimum wage?', 'Target recently announced a rise in its minimum wage to eleven dollars per hour, and banks, including Wells Fargo, PNC Financial Services, and Fifth Third Bank, announced a fifteen-dollar minimum wage.35']

['What else are you interested in studying?', 'The American Sustainable Business Council, in conjunction with Business for a Fair Wage, surveyed more than five hundred small businesses, and the results were surprising.']

['Did they like the idea of raising the minimum wage?', 'A clear majority (58%–66%, depending on region) supported raising the minimum wage to at least ten dollars per hour.36 Business owners were not simply being ethical; most understand that their business would benefit from an increase in consumers’ purchasing power, and that this, in turn, would help the general economy.']

['What was the statement of Frank Knapp?', 'Frank Knapp, CEO of the South Carolina Small Business Chamber of Commerce representing five thousand business owners, said a higher minimum wage “will put more money in the hands of 300,000 South Carolinians who make less than ten dollars per hour and they will spend it here in our local economies.']
['What is another benefit of the minimum wage increase?', 'This minimum wage increase will also benefit another 150,000 employees who will have their wages adjusted.']
['Did it raise the revenue of the state?', 'The resulting net $500 million increase in state GDP will be good for small businesses and good for the economy of South Carolina.']
['What was the next important thing?', '”37']

['What can businesses do to help workers move to, or stay in, the middle class?', 'In addition to paying a higher wage, businesses can help workers move to, or stay in, the middle class in other ways.']

['What other ways can they help workers?', 'For decades, some companies have hired many full-time workers as independent contractors because it saves them money on a variety of employee benefits they do not have to offer as a result.']

['How does that practice shift the burden to the workers?', 'However, that practice shifts the burden to the workers, who now have to pay the full cost of their health insurance, workers’ compensation, unemployment benefits, time off, and payroll taxes.']

['What is the average cost of employee compensation per hour in September 2017?', 'A recent Department of Labor study indicates that employer costs for employee compensation averaged $35.64 per hour worked in September 2017; wages and salaries averaged $24.33 per hour worked and accounted for 68 percent of these costs, whereas benefit costs averaged $11.31 and accounted for the remaining 32 percent.']

['What happened next?', 'That means if employees on the payroll were paid as independent contractors, their pay would effectively be about one-third less, assuming they purchased benefits on their own.']

['Are there any other interesting aspects of the article?', 'The 30 percent difference companies save by hiring independent contractors is often the margin between being in the middle class and falling below it.']

['What is the major topic covered in this section?', 'Yet sympathy for raising the minimum wage at either the federal or state level to sustain the middle class or reduce poverty in general has not been unanimous.']

['What is the main reason that some economists have questioned whether a positive correlation exists between greater wages and a lowering of the poverty rate?', 'Indeed, some economists have questioned whether a positive correlation exists between greater wages and a lowering of the poverty rate.']

Wascher, a long-time economic researcher on the staff of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.']
['What are the results of their work?', 'They argue that, however well-meaning such efforts might be, simply raising the minimum wage can be counterproductive to driving down poverty.']
['What are their reasons for not using the right calculus?', 'Rather, they maintain, the right calculus for achieving this goal is much more complex.']
['What did they say?', 'As they put it, “we are hard-pressed to imagine a compelling argument for a higher minimum wage when it neither helps low-income families nor reduces poverty.”']

['What was the greatest problem you were confronted with?', 'The issue of income inequality is of particular significance as it relates to women.']
['How was this determined?', 'According to the World Economic Forum (WEF), gender inequality is strongly associated with income inequality.']

['Did they study the same country or regions?', 'The WEF studied the association between the two phenomena in 140 countries over the past twenty years and discovered they are linked virtually everywhere, not only in developing nations.']

['What did they do to fix these problems?', 'The issue of pay discrimination is addressed elsewhere in this textbook; however, the issue merits mention here as a part of the bigger picture of equality in the workplace.']
['What was their conclusion?', 'Adding to the disparity in income between men and women is the reality that many women are single mothers with dependent children and sometimes grandchildren.']
['What did they conclude?', 'Hence, any reduction in their earning power has direct implications for their dependents, too, constituting injustice to multiple generations.']

['What is pay equity as a corollary of income equality?', 'According to multiple studies, including those by the American Association of University Women and the Pew Research Center, on average, women are paid approximately 80 percent of what men are paid.41 Laws that attempt to address this issue have not eradicated the problem.']
['What steps did some state take to address the problem?', 'A recent trend is to take legislative action at the state rather than the federal level.']

['What other steps have state taken to address the issue?', 'A New Jersey law, for example, was named the Diane B. Allen Equal Pay Act to honor a retired state senator who experienced pay discrimination.']

['What is the strongest such law in the country?', 'It will be the strongest such law in the country, allowing victims of discrimination to seek redress for up to six years of underpayment, and monetary damages for a prevailing plaintiff will be tripled.']
['What was the most significant part of the law?', 'The most significant part of the law, however, is a seemingly small change in wording that will have a big impact.']

['What was the change in wording?', 'Rather than requiring “equal pay for equal work,” as does the federal law and most state laws aimed at the gender wage gap, the Diane B. Allen Equal Pay Act will require “equal pay for substantially similar work.”']

['What does this mean?', 'This means that if a New Jersey woman has a different title than her male colleague but performs the same kinds of tasks and has the same level of responsibility, she must be paid the same.']

['Are there any other important aspects of the article?', 'The new law recognizes that slight differences in job titles are sometimes used to justify pay differences but in reality are often arbitrary.']
['What other state has a similar law?', 'Minnesota recently passed a similar law, but it applies only to state government employees, not private-sector workers.']

['What is the law that mandates that women be paid the same for comparable jobs?', 'It mandates that women be paid the same for comparable jobs and analyzes the work performed on the basis of how much knowledge, problem solving, and responsibility is required, and on working conditions rather than merely on job titles.']

['What is the trend in the US?', 'Ethical business managers will see this trend as an effort to address an ethical issue that has existed for well over a century and will follow the lead of states such as New Jersey and Minnesota.']

['How can pay equity be solved?', 'A company can help solve this problem by changing the way it uses job titles and creating a compensation system built on the ideas behind these two laws, which focus on job characteristics and not titles.']

['What are some of the interesting parts about this article?', 'Rhode Island, along with Boulder, Colorado, and Berkeley, California, led the way in enacting legislation recognizing individuals as guardians, not owners, of their animals, thus giving animals legal status beyond being just items of property.']

['What else was significant about this movement?', 'Many U.S. colleges now teach courses on animal rights law, there is strong support for granting fundamental legal rights to animals, and some attorneys, scientists, and ethicists dedicate their careers to animal rights.']

['What happened in the late nineteenth century?', 'The animal movement started in the late nineteenth century when the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (ASPCA) was formed, along with the American Humane Association.']
['How long has the American Welfare Institute been around?', 'The American Welfare Institute and the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS) were established in the 1950s.']

['What was the first federal animal protection law?', 'The first federal animal protection law, the Humane Slaughter Act, was passed in the 1950s to avoid unnecessary suffering to farm animals (ten billion of which are killed every year).']

['What was the most important U.S. law forbidding cruelty to animals in laboratory settings?', 'The most important U.S. law forbidding cruelty to animals in laboratory settings was enacted in 1966; the Animal Welfare']
['What did the act require?', 'Act requires basic humane conditions to be maintained for animals in testing facilities.']
['What was the modern animal rights social movement?', 'Finally, in the 1970s and 1980s, the modern animal rights social movement emerged.']
['How did this movement effect people?', 'It has led to an increased awareness of animal ethics by consumers and businesses.']

['What is the most important thing to know about the passage?', 'However, despite significant progress, research using animals for product testing continues to be controversial in the United States, particularly because improved technology has offered humane and effective alternatives.']

['What else did you learn?', 'The use of animals in biomedical research has drawn slightly less negative reaction than in consumer product testing, because of the more critical nature of the research.']

['What else did you discover?', 'Though animal welfare laws have ameliorated some of the pain of animals used in biomedical research, ethical concerns remain, and veterinarians and physicians are demanding change, as are animal rights groups and policy and ethics experts.']

['What else did you learn?', 'Increased integration of ethics in business conduct is operating alongside the desire to recognize animal rights, the entitlement of nonhuman animals to ethical treatment.']
['What is the most important part of this paper for you?', 'Concern for the welfare of animals beyond pets brings us to the agribusiness industry.']
['What are some groups to help out with that?', 'This is where groups such as the ASPCA and HSUS have been particularly active.']
['What is agribusiness?', 'Agribusiness is a huge industry that provides us with the food we eat, including plant-based and animal-based foodstuffs.']

['How has the industry changed over the past century?', 'The industry has changed significantly over the past century, evolving from one consisting primarily of family and/or small businesses to a much larger one dominated mostly by large corporations.']

['What are some ethical issues that are relevant to the food industry?', 'Aspects of this business with relevant and interrelated ethical questions range from ecology, animal rights, and economics to food safety and long-term sustainability.']

['What other aspects of ethics?', 'To achieve a high level of sustainability in the world’s food supply chain, all stakeholders—the political sector, the business sector, the finance sector, the academic sector, and the consumer—must work in concert to achieve an optimal result, and a cost-benefit analysis of ethics in the food industry should include a recognition of all their concerns.']
['What are some important points?', 'Experts predict that for us to meet the food needs of the world’s population, we will need to double food production over the next fifty years.']

['What can be done to get more food?', 'Given this, a high priority in the agribusiness industry ought to be to meet this demand for food at a reasonable price with products that are not a threat to human health and safety, animal health, or the limited resources in Earth’s environment.']
['What is being done about the environment?', 'However, to do so requires attention to factors such as soil and surface water conservation and protection of natural land and water areas.']

['What is the most important thing to remember about the passage?', 'Furthermore, the treatment of animals by everyone in the livestock chain (e.g., livestock farmers, dealers, fish farmers, animal transporters, slaughterhouses) must be appropriate for a society with high legal and ethical standards.']
['What is the document about?', 'The food chain can be truly sustainable only when it safeguards the social welfare and living environment of the people working in it.']
['What does this mean?', 'This means eliminating corruption, human rights violations (including forced labor and child labor), and poor working conditions.']

['What else does this mean?', 'We must also encourage and empower consumers to make informed choices, which includes enforcing labeling regulations and the posting of relevant and accurate dietary information.']
['What are the main ideas of the article?', 'Finally, an analysis of the food supply chain must also include an awareness of people’s food needs and preferences.']

['What needs and preferences do people have?', 'For example, the fact that growing numbers of consumers are adopting vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free, or non–genetically modified organism diets is now apparent at responsive restaurants, grocery stores, and employer-provided cafés.']

['What is the most important fact in this article?', 'For many, the ethical treatment of animals remains a philosophic issue; however, some rules about what foods are morally acceptable and how they are prepared for consumption (e.g., halal or kosher) are also grounded in faith, so animal rights have religious implications, too.']
['How did this material influence you?', 'All in all, consumers’ growing ethical sensitivity about what we eat could ultimately transform agribusiness.']
['What would they do?', 'More acreage might be assigned to growing fruits and vegetables relative to those given over to livestock grazing, for instance.']
['What else might be revealed about slaughterhouse processes?', 'Or revelations about slaughterhouse processes may reduce our acceptance of the ways in which meat is processed for consumption.']
['What would happen to the agriculture industry?', 'The economic consequences for agribusiness of such changes are difficult to underestimate.']

['What are the other points in the study material?', 'Viewpoints about animals used in medical research are changing in very significant ways and have resulted in a variety of initiatives seeking alternatives to animal testing.']

['What alternatives were sought to animal testing?', 'As an example, in conjunction with professionals from human and veterinary medicine and the law, the Yale University Hastings Program in Ethics and Health Policy, a bioethics research institute, is seeking alternatives to animal testing that focus on animal welfare.']

['What are the animal research methods?', 'Animals such as monkeys and dogs are used in medical research ranging from the study of Parkinson disease to toxicity testing and studies of drug interactions and allergies.']
['How are the research methods beneficial?', 'There is no question that medical research is a valuable and important practice.']
['What is the question?', 'The question is whether the use of animals is a necessary or even best practice for producing the most reliable results.']

['What are the alternatives to animal testing?', 'Alternatives include the use of patient-drug databases, virtual drug trials, computer models and simulations, and noninvasive imaging techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging and computed tomography scans.43']
['What are other methods?', 'Other techniques, such as microdosing, use humans not as test animals but as a means to improve the accuracy and reliability of test results.']
['What are the other methods?', 'In vitro methods based on human cell and tissue cultures, stem cells, and genetic testing methods are also increasingly available.']
['What is the name of the document that is the source of the loudest outcry?', 'As for consumer product testing, which produces the loudest outcry, the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic']
['Do they have to test their products on animals?', 'Act does not require that animal tests be conducted to demonstrate the safety of cosmetics.']
['Why do companies test formulations on animals?', 'Rather, companies test formulations on animals in an attempt to protect themselves from liability if a consumer is harmed by a product.']

['What other things are there to know about animal testing?', 'However, a significant amount of new research shows that consumer products such as cosmetics can be accurately tested for safety without the abuse of animals.']
['What do some companies do instead?', 'Some companies may resist altering their methods of conducting research, but a growing number are now realizing that their customers are demanding a change.']

['What do you learn about the US?', 'Like virtually every other industrialized nation, the United States permits medical experimentation on animals, with few limitations (assuming sufficient scientific justification).']

['What are the laws that exist to limit unnecessary animal suffering?', 'The goal of any laws that exist is not to ban such tests but rather to limit unnecessary animal suffering by establishing standards for the humane treatment and housing of animals in laboratories.']

['What kind of legal and regulatory approach to animal testing is discussed here?', 'As explained by Stephen Latham, the director of the Interdisciplinary Center for Bioethics at Yale,44 possible legal and regulatory approaches to animal testing vary on a continuum from strong government regulation and monitoring of all experimentation at one end, to a self-regulated approach that depends on the ethics of the researchers at the other end.']
['What other countries have different regulatory systems?', 'The United Kingdom has the most significant regulatory scheme, whereas Japan uses the self-regulation approach.']
['How does the US system compare to the UK system?', 'The U.S. approach is somewhere in the middle, the result of a gradual blending of the two approaches.']
['What else did you find interesting?', 'A movement has begun to win legal recognition of chimpanzees as the near-equivalent of humans, therefore, as “persons” with legal rights.']

['What is the analogy between the effort and environmental justice?', 'This is analogous to the effort called environmental justice, an attempt to do the same for the environment (discussed in the section on Environmental Justice in Three Special Stakeholders: Society, the Environment, and Government).']

['Was there anything else interesting you found?', 'A nonprofit organization in Florida, the Nonhuman Rights Project, is an animal advocacy group that has hired attorneys to present a theory in court that two chimpanzees (Tommy and Kiko) have the legal standing and right to be freed from cages to live in an outdoor sanctuary.']

['What is the nonhuman rights project?', 'In this case, the attorneys have been trying for years to get courts to grant the chimps habeas corpus (Latin for “you shall have the body”), a right people have under the U.S. Constitution when held against their will.']
['Did they win?', 'To date, this effort has been unsuccessful.']

['What other interesting fact is there in the article?', 'The courts have extended certain constitutional rights to corporations, such as the First Amendment right to free speech (in the 2010 Citizens United case).']
['What is the difference between this case and the previous one?', 'Therefore, some reason, a logical extension of that concept would hold that animals and the environment have rights as well.']

['What are some other important aspects of the article?', 'In cosmetic testing, the United States has relatively few laws protecting animals, whereas about forty other nations have taken more direct action.']
['What happened in 2013?', 'In 2013, the European Union banned animal testing for cosmetics and the marketing and sale of cosmetics tested on animals.']
['What did Norway do?', 'Norway and Switzerland passed similar laws.']

['Were there other countries that banned animal testing?', 'Outside Europe, a variety of other nations, including Guatemala, India, Israel, New Zealand, South Korea, Taiwan, and Turkey, have also passed laws to ban or limit cosmetic animal testing.']
['What was the biggest threat to U.S. cosmetic companies?', 'U.S. cosmetic companies will not be able to sell their products in any of these countries unless they change their practices.']
['What was an alternative for them?', 'The Humane Cosmetics']
['What was the next step in the process?', 'Act has been introduced but not yet passed by Congress.']
['What would the bill do?', 'If enacted, it would end cosmetics testing on animals in the United States and ban the import of animal-tested cosmetics.']
['What is the current antiregulatory environment?', '46 However, in the current antiregulatory environment, passage seems unlikely.']

['What is the realistic alternative approach?', 'According to the Humane Society of the United States, a more realistic alternative approach is to develop nonanimal tests that could provide more human safety data, including information about cancer and birth defects related to new products.']
['What else was discussed?', 'Consumer pressure can also influence change.']

['What is the message that consumers can send to businesses?', 'If consumer purchases demonstrate a preference for cruelty-free cosmetics and support ending cosmetics animal testing, businesses will get the message.']

['What are some examples of companies that have ceased testing cosmetics on animals?', 'Almost one hundred companies have already ceased testing cosmetics on animals, including The Body Shop, Burt’s Bees, E.L.F.']
['What brands did they discontinue?', 'Cosmetics, Lush, and Tom’s of Maine.']
['Did they all do so for ethical treatment?', 'Lists of such firms are maintained by People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals and similar organizations.']

['What else do you want to know?', 'Companies will be wise to adapt to the increasing level of public awareness and consumer expectations, not least because U.S. culture now incorporates pets in almost every aspect of life.']

['What is the practice of assigning or denying coverage for certain policies, such as auto, homeowners, or business insurance, on the basis of the geographic neighborhoods where applicants for such coverage live, particularly inner-city neighborhoods?', 'Redlining is the practice of assigning or denying coverage for certain policies, such as auto, homeowners, or business insurance, on the basis of the geographic neighborhoods where applicants for such coverage live, particularly inner-city neighborhoods.']

['What is the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act?', 'Health care reform on a major scale emerged in the United States with the passage of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, more commonly known as the Affordable Care Act (ACA), in March 2010, during the Obama Administration.']
['What are the opinions about Obamacare?', 'The ACA (so-called Obamacare) represents a controversial plan that strikes its opponents as socialist.']
['Why is it considered socialist?', 'For its supporters, however, it is the first effective and comprehensive plan to extend affordable health care to the widest segment of the U.S. population.']
['Are there other opinions about the ACA?', 'Furthermore, like most new federal policies, it has undergone tweaks and revision each year since becoming law.']

['What does the ACA mandate?', 'The ACA mandates a certain level of preventive care, a choice of physicians and health care facilities, coverage at no extra cost for individuals with preexisting health conditions, protection against the cancellation of coverage solely on the basis of becoming ill, and mental health and substance abuse treatment, all of which must be met by carriers that participate in the plan.']
['What else does it cover?', 'The ACA also permits its holders to select from a number of marketplace plans as opposed to the limited number of plans typically offered by any given employer.']
['What was the plan for?', 'All in all, it is a far-reaching and complex plan whose full implications for employers and their employees have yet to be appreciated.']

['What were the effects of the Affordable Care Act on the workforce?', 'Preliminary results seem to indicate that employer-provided coverage on a comprehensive scale remains a cheaper alternative for those workers eligible to receive it.']

['Are there any other interesting facts about the article?', 'Given the general efficiency of group insurance policies provided by U.S. employers, an ethical issue for all managers is whether these policies offer the best care for the greatest number of employees and so should be the responsibility of management to offer whenever it is possible to do so.']

['What is the current law regarding health insurance?', 'Current law requires all companies employing fifty or more workers to make insurance available to that part of their workforce that qualifies for such coverage (e.g., by virtue of hours worked).']

['What does the law say to smaller businesses?', 'Even if the law does not require it, we hold that an ethical obligation resides with small businesses to do everything in their power to provide this coverage for their employees.']

['What is the ethical question raised by job sharing?', 'The ethical question raised by job sharing boils down to whether the employer is hiring job sharers to improve productivity and meet employee preferences, or hiring part-time workers to improve profitability at the employees’ expense.']

['What is the practice of offering flexible hours, or flextime?', 'The practice of offering flexible hours, or flextime, lets employees choose their own start and finish time each day, arriving and leaving earlier or later than the normal 9-to-5 workday.']

['How is that different from reduced schedule?', 'Some companies allow a compressed work week that caters to the efficient employee who can get a week’s work done in less than forty hours.']

['What are the implications of these job sharing and flextime?', 'All these variations allow employers to recruit a more diverse workforce.']
['How can these changes improve the lives of people who are employed?', 'No longer is it necessary that someone be free of weekday responsibilities to have full-time work and gainful employment.']
['How can these changes benefit customers?', 'Flextime also benefits clients and customers because companies can extend their hours of operation when workers are willing to cover flexible shifts.']
['What are the questions related to this?', 'Ethical employers base the decision to allow flextime on a clear and well-written policy that relies on objective job-related criteria.']

['What is important to know about this topic?', '60 Employers should also be aware of the law; in some states, daily work hours are set by law, and allowing some employees to work more than eight hours a day might require payment of overtime.']

['What is the access economy?', 'The access economy is essentially a resource circulation system in which consumers participate on both sides of a transaction, as both providers and obtainers of resources (the transaction is usually facilitated by a third party acting as a go-between).']

['What is the sharing economy?', 'The model, sometimes called peer-to-peer (or P2P), is particularly popular when the asset is expensive to obtain and is not fully consumed by the user (such as a house or condo).']

['What is the traditional capitalist economic model?', 'In the traditional capitalist economic model, goods are bought and sold by businesses and individuals, but in the access or sharing economy, goods and services are traded on the basis of access rather than ownership.']
['What is the access economy?', 'In this business model, owners make money from underused assets.']
['What are examples of this business model?', 'The global online hospitality marketplace is an example.']

['What are other examples of the access economy?', 'Car owners using the service RelayRides make an average of $250 a month from allowing others to use their cars.']
['What does the access economy do?', 'This helps consumers supplement their incomes or even finance the purchase of the assets they share.']

['What are some of the original sharing-economy businesses?', 'Many of the original sharing-economy businesses are now household names, including Airbnb, Uber, and Lyft; thousands more are part of the P2P decentralized markets.']

['what are the online platform economy?', 'Most sharing or collaborative economy business models use the Internet to facilitate transactions, so it might be more accurate to refer to them as part of the online platform economy.']

['what are the business models?', 'However, whereas some facilitate the renting of assets, such as real estate (think Airbnb), others are essentially selling labor (think Task Rabbit), and some bridge the two categories by offering a combination (think Lyft) (see Figure 10.7).']

['What do the business models have in common?', 'The new business models all have something in common, however: a decentralized and democratized marketplace featuring broad-scale participation, with consumers serving multiple roles.']
['What is the main idea of the passage?', 'Online and digital business models allow almost anyone to start a business from scratch in what some call the democratization of free enterprise.']

['Why was this important?', 'An economy so open to new players is a significant step toward increased buyer access to goods and services at all levels, even as it raises legitimate questions about how to ensure trust between the transacting parties.']
['What is one issue facing the access economy?', 'One issue facing the access economy is regulation.']

['What else is it regulated for?', 'Some cities have passed ordinances to limit real estate rentals to minimum stays of a week or a month; shorter stays will be considered hotel rentals subject to regulations such as health and safety code rules.']

['What other regulation is related to ride sharing?', 'In the ride-sharing segment, some cities have said drivers must undergo the same scrutiny as taxi or limousine drivers, such as fingerprinting, commercial licensing, training, and background checks.']

['What does the access economy mean?', 'The access economy presents an ethical and regulatory challenge for all levels of government—balancing the need to have at least some rules to protect consumers with the desire to allow competition from new business models.']

['What are the problems of this?', 'Big businesses are lobbying legislative bodies to apply the same regulation to the access economy as to the traditional economy in an effort to reduce or eliminate the threat of competition.']
['What is important about this?', 'This, in turn, raises an ethical question for society as a whole.']

['What is the gig economy?', 'Opportunities for limited-term employment, sometimes referred to as “gigs,” have existed for decades in the music and entertainment industry; they have even been likened to the widespread small-scale self-employment typical of the pre-union and pre-Industrial eras.65']

['What do you find interesting about the gig economy?', 'This offers workers, and perhaps even managers, a new set of advantages and disadvantages in the employment equation.']
